syk9mhZXDKXNVMOoM3BMtQ.text: AMAZING.Good prices, and such delicious food! I ate here a month ago so I don't remember what I ordered, but the experience was unforgettable.Also unforgettable is the male host who got mad at me because I changed my mind about sitting inside, and wanted to sit outside. So cut the indecisiveness so the host doesn't get mad at you, and this place is 100% perfect =)

dPGGclBa9cB01XvH4x9qag.text: A friend recommended Busaba Eathai. I tried the calamari which was fantastic. My husband who hates calamari liked it. My husband had the fried chicken dinner with brown rice. He said it was good but not fantastic. I had sticky rice and chicken with a side of spicy cucumbers. The spicy cucumber were very interesting, but I liked it. The food was good but not great.The restaurant is very casual with picnic style tables. We actually sat at the counter because the restaurant was full. I was pleased with customer service and would be willing to return.

F2cGiuHuDgcfXVAJvHAqyg.text: (Let's get the cons out of the way first.) The communal-style dining is done better on Wagama's long benches, where you sit at opposite sides of the table; here, the tables are square, meaning that you and your party perch around one corner, making conversation a bit of a challenge when it's busy, and when it's busy, it gets very, very noisy...(Right; now on to the pros) Don't worry about the noise, though; you'll be too busy enjoying the food to be bothering with conversation. Our party of 4 had 6/7 dishes between us (not including rice), and everything was top notch - nicely presented, with wonderful, fresh flavours bursting out of every bite. A couple of other reviewers have complained that service was slow, but that wasn't our experience. Although we had to wait a while for drinks to arrive, the food was delivered to the table very promptly.  Pro tip: Get there early. We *left* at 7.15 and the queue was already 50-odd people long, and considering how many other great eateries there are within spitting distance of Busaba, they must be doing something right if people are prepared to wait in the rain for a table. Can't wait to go back and try some of the other things on the menu.Bonus tip: Try the calamari. Forget the pale, rubbery bits of elastic band that you've had in other restaurants; these guys know how to cook it to perfection.

V8fAPkJ1XtqpminPwVp3aw.text: Stopped there on a recent trip to London as it was near my hotel. Tried their spicy beef and rice, which was pretty good, and the papaya salad (ordered it not spicy) which was also good. My wife ordered their chicken butternut squash stir fry, and liked it. The problem is that the dishes are tiny, the chicken dish had 3 small pieces, a few cubes of squash, a bit of onion and overall was the size of a small appetizer. The salad and beef were not much bigger. Considering the price, it's almost a ripoff. Will probably not go back.

sWP7K_5IifbfQl80UIaw9Q.text: When I entered the restaurant, the feel was of warmth and the food made the experience unforgettable. I visit Busaba every time I am in London and this has never changed.The menu is simple and quite interesting. I always get side dishes with main course dishes because they just make it a lot better. The fruit drinks are refreshing and a must try.Overall, an absolutely amazing restaurant with every penny worth spent.

mgmlKG00_pmzmB5YRZKw8A.text: I was really excited to eat here based on all the good reviews, and also because i've seen ridiculous queues outside this restaurant, and also the one in Hoxton. i came, i ate, i left pretty indifferent. i'm no expert on thai food, and it is definitely not my favourite cuisine, so do bare that in mind when reading this review! the atmosphere in here is dark, atmospheric and has a nice buzz to it. obviously if you don't like being social or sitting with other people, you might not enjoy the seating arrangements, but they work well for me. i ordered the coconut prawns and sticky rice (i love coconut. l.o.v.e it!), and my boyfriend the fried chicken and coconut rice (i thought going for coconut rice and coconut prawns was overkill, but i really wanted to, BOO!). i didn't think the portions were huge, but they were certainly acceptable, and kept me filled up all evening, anything extra would have been eaten, and enjoyed, but not necessary! if you do have a big appetite though, i would recommend ordering some sides to share perhaps. the food for me was just okay. i'm glad to have tried it, but i'm also equally glad that i can now take it off my bookmarks! i probably wouldn't venture back here with the plethora of eateries in london that i want to try, but i would probably recommend it if someone was looking for thai food in a central location.also - i didn't think that £30 all in for two stirfries, two rice and two diet cokes that was reasonably priced at all! the waitress who served us towards the end was scottish, HI SCOTTISH HOME BRO, and really friendly and enthusiastic, so i think she is also worth a mention.

ZN-94dSfiUTe4zFHZlEkUw.text: Excellent thai food!One warning: when they say "spicy", they mean it.  So, don't throw on your cowboy hat like this American did and assume you can take it-- it's hot. Excellent pricing, great drinks, and what an amazing space!

2kYr4ykB1m_AUdbuXzq-PA.text: Good points:Cleanfunctionalpolite friendly servicetasty foodvery reasonable pricesspaciousgood location for people watchingBad points:portions not generousservice a little too speedy for our mood that eveningAll in all, a winner. Will definitley be returning due to the location and prices.

4WM6ZrU9RRvfUWOoyFNoQA.text: So solid!  The calamari is outstanding and good pad thai.  It is popular and noisy, but had to say we enjoyed the seats at the window for a bit more private conversation.The grilled beef by the way was nice and spicy.Service could have been better but all and all--a great place with a happening vibe and solid food.

7x5DgmVa1JMVO38bhr_kIw.text: I don't remember how many times I've been here.. let's just say I've been to 4 different locations and had one basically as my front porch (they keep opening new locals - not my fault they are scattered everywhere ;))  One would automatically think that if there are way too many chains the food takes on a different personality of it's own and decides to stop being so great.  However, Busaba has definitely kept it's demeanor and deliciousness - even though sometimes it can get a bit salty - that's what the rice is for..! I'm all about trying different things on their menu, while my friends like to stick to their usual... but if you want to stick on the safe side, try the Thai CalamariPad Thai, and Green Curry... standard.All I know is that it's a definite go to when I'm craving some Thai food that's not too ridiculously priced, even if the service can be spotty.

iT5p5YxKqai5aNPAfRezXw.text: Great for groups. You may end up sitting with another group as well. It's a little noisy but service is excellent and so is the food. Loved the Mussaman duck curry and the phad phak.

4-QZLLT9KOk89mr-8dAgfA.text: Ooh, I really really really like this place, when I walk inside, the smells remind me of Thailand, and from all the Thai places I have tried in London, this place seems to be the most authentic with regards to the ingredients and flavours.It does seem to use the best ingredients (Fresh peppercorns and good quality meat!). The food is generally consistent (Squid starter is fab!!) so I am always satisfied when I leave.It looses a star cause It's a bit on the pricey side, compared to other Asian eateries and if you have a drink then the bill goes up a fair bit.  Good thing is that there are quite a few of them around town now.Recommend!

Djv_owDNsmCSs5iUjdYDdw.text: Lovely restaurant our 3rd visit. Came in early birds after a theatre matinee. Great service and delightful wait staff. Shame the coconut AND the Thai rice selections were unavailable. The signature pad Thai with crab and shrimp made my 84 year father very happy. My tofu was a v small portion but delicious. However my husband was v disappointed by his shrimp soup. 4 shrimps and most of the rest of the solid Ingredients were inedible- lemon grass stems and ginger chunks. The bowl was really only half full, very mean with the glass noodles too. I had to give him most of my rice. So.... Maybe I'm spoilt by authentic Thai restaurants in LA. Unfortunately I feel like this place still has the same delightful vibe but has slipped to quite a mediocre standard in the quality and value department. Sadly I am eating peanuts not paying peanuts.

ju6_6mVdHyPYAReMTsXnPA.text: Good food, fast unobtrusive service. The benchmark meal for a Thai restaurant - Thai green chicken curry over jasmine rice washed down with a glass of merlot, all for under £20. Good hot spicy flavoursome green curry. Fluffy jasmine rice. Good merlot. No queues the night I was there (it *was* raining). As it is a fusion style restaurant the decor is a little spartan, but the location is good and central. Overall, very good and I will certainly go back! :)

26SeNo27gDPqOP6yAmUOsg.text: I love this place...if your in London you must pass by!its not chic and glamourous, the shared tables make for interesting conversations.the food is amazing and the atmosphere is quaint!pop in at Bar Italia for an awesome cappucino near by and you have a night of magic!

wPEBamJib2AjbT7M4CIBEQ.text: Nice place in Soho, dim lights and cozy. Big tables to cher with other guests,(good or bad? depends if the people sitting next to you have take an shower or not, not in my case:(,) Food is good! actually much better then hakkasan( yes i know Chinese vs Thai, but Busaba is better)So if you want a nice simple dinner, the place is perfect

5446IVEyLZ_JobWBP0-8sA.text: This was one of my favorite restaurants in London and some of the best Thai food I have ever eaten. Be prepared to wait though - this trendy restaurant is very popular and there is usually quite a long line out the door for dinner on Friday and Saturday nights. The unique wrap-around communal seating arrangement gave the restaurant an interesting vibe, but it was hard to include people seated on the other end of the bench in conversation during dinner.I had an awesome guava bellini with my meal, but it was very expensive for a tiny, tiny glass. The food was well-prepared, but it was also on the pricier side. I really liked that Busaba had many more interesting menu options than the typical Thai noodle and rice dishes, though. Thai restaurants in California tend to have HUGE portions, so the artfully plated normal-sized portions here surprised me a little. I definitely preferred the more manageable portions though - leftover Thai food never tastes quite as good the next day!

my7YK3_uWUns2n9AT3Nkrw.text: The last time I ate pad Thai, I was in Bangkok. HAHAHA IN YOUR FACE oh no wait it was at Busaba Eathai.  Fail.However, it's so good that just a small taste and I might as well be back in Thailand, along the Khao San Road, with 50p fisherman pants being waved in my face, reclining in a bar decorated with puffer fish, sipping on a Chang, contemplating a foot massage.  Good times.The Thai calamari has probably never been anywhere near South East Asia even whilst paddling along in the sea as a carefree, innocent squid, but I'll forgive them because it's the tastiest calamari I have eaten in my life, ever.  I would lay money on the fact that I am happier whilst chewing that bad boy than it ever was whilst alive and THAT'S WHY I EAT MEAT.  Pots of tea stretch to four cups and come with two biscuits.  Winner!  I love a free biscuit.  It makes me feel like I'm at the hairdressers.I know that Busaba is technically a chain, and I'm morally against them in Soho, but they pull it off. I don't want to love them, but I do.  And I think the Wardour St branch may be the original, so that soothes my conscience.I can't quite get over them charging £2.50 for a small bottle of Coke.  And you have to sit at a table with Other People which grates against every one of my senses as a born-and-bred Londoner.  But the ambience is fab and the service usually pretty speedy.  Of an evening the queues stretch all the way down Wardour St, but at 1pm you'll walk straight in, making it a great spot for lunch which is slightly special, but since the mains are all under £15, not too special.I've been to Thailand you know.Mmmmmm.

9AV05PvRxO8dsOB8Akxk3g.text: We chose to eat here while on vacation because of all the great reviews we read on yelp. I was unsure what to order so our waitress recommended I get the pad thai and calamari. The pad thai was good, but nothing out of the extraordinary. The calamari however, was exceptional. The service was sub par to what we're used to, but each country has different standards of customer service so I feel I'm not really in a position to judge. I'm giving Busaba Eathai an extra star for the calamari.

T6LWajS2WvZN5tvVmZaiDQ.text: Delicious today for lunch as always. we had the seng chan pad that ( with huge prawns and crabmeat) crab and prawn stirfried rice ( delish,) the awesome calamari with peppercorns, spring rolls and a 3 beers.Service prompt, the place was packed and I quite like the communal tables ( even though no-one talks to you!)£35 for 2, and we were stuffed! Service can be a bit haphazard and the third beer had to be asked for but all in all , great food and a lovely restaurant.

P7EkeVUmHeTvbG7lADsv6w.text: We had a great time at Busaba. The food was great. The service was good. We came at the right time, it  was a short queue.We had the ginger and peppercorn Thai calamari. It was very good (though, it did not include the tentacles? boooooo). Since every Thai restaurant I have ever been to cooks with different spice levels; I tried to determine from our restaurant server how spicy the food is prepared at Busaba (or what is the best way to convey to them how spicy we want it)...... Example:  Spice level 1- 5 or 1- 10 with  10 being the spiciest, etc....  The server really didn't give us a straight answer so we just said  'Thai spicy' the food came out real  spicy, the way we like it. The Red Lamb Curry was very good. Kate loved her Pat king Talay dish. The side of Chinese broccoli with garlic andshiitake mushrooms was delish ' !!  The brown rice was good. The Singha beers were flowing.We would return to Busaba.

IeMywWXwc4nGExZs2lhCRw.text: When I first ate from Busaba around 2010, it was an exceptional experience. As the chain grows, the food is becoming average with each passing year.

glsENCrTGV12KzXbZ-reVw.text: A tasty way to end an evening.A few of us were looking on Yelp! for somewhere to eat after an evening of wine and Canapes and stumbled across this place.We were told to order quickly as they were closing, so we quickly sat down and scouted the menu. I settled on the Char-grilled chickenspicy cucumber salad and coconut rice and a glass of the finest tap water they had.The speed of service was efficient bordering on rushed, but the food was delish!I'd like to go back again when we have a bit more time to enjoy ourselves!

WVfT9XmbAJ7jkQclyxRPGQ.text: Seriously, it looks more like a Thai fast food... average food, chaotic dining room... overrated!

N4zXUkzHogfw1r1yp7vatg.text: Hands down the best Thai food I have had while abroad. I came here last summer and stumbled over this restaurant. The location is great, the restaurant itself is very inviting and is great for both large groups or an intimate date. I've been here 4 times now and each time I've been delighted with my meal. The pink grapefruit mojitos are absolute heaven and the smoked chicken noodle dish is outstanding! You of course must try the pad Thai as well. I will always be back to this restaurant that's for sure!

1XZpLYIm5rsyRh9Lw9M2Pw.text: Okay, yes I'm still catching up on reviews from May, but I can't leave this place out, this place is absolutely unbelievable! The Thai food is amazing and I'm so happy Steven M. dragged me way too many city blocks to get to this place. The atmosphere is fun and flirty, parties are sat at huge square tables capable of sitting 20 or so so it would be great for large gouts. We were a group of 3 and it was perfectly intimate. The food is absolutely unreal and the grapefruit mojitos are fantastic! I have never cleared my plate so quickly, get the pad thai! I hope I'm in London again soon because I absolutely will be jaded here!

uqHWdTv305qeRheiiwtO8A.text: Very crowded and extremely slow service. Food was ok though, but slightly over-priced for thai food! Tried their pad kwetio which was too salty, and mussaman duck curry wasn't exceptional either. Came with high expectations but was disappointed.

aFUVGxK5Q1bDYxDSnM5lXA.text: Great athmosfere, if you fancy a teenager or young people style place. I have no complaints about the wait, you can choose several types of Thai food, although I do not love canteen style dining. I have even heard the chain restaurant is from the same owner of wagamama, which would then make perfect sense.I do recommend it for the quality of the food. It is a great experience, and worth at least giving it a go, even if you hate the cons I have cited above. It is a good cost benefit experience after all.

-xRBxqFmXyalz-0llZXYBA.text: As far as affordable fancy London restaurants go, this one is definitely one of them! What I love about this city is that you can get the most amazing meals for just £10-£13 per meal, and in a upscale atmosphere, with excellent service, value for money and even presentation!Busaba is one of these places, where you can have so many different experiences such as an amazing, fun night out with a big group of friends, or an intimate dinner on a date without the tension.The atmosphere is dark, relaxed and busy but I love it. Even as you walk in, there are incredible scented smells welcoming you and making you feel like you are in Asia for a moment. There is a coat rack, and plenty of room for everyone to sit and get comfortable at the big tables.There is a real feel of 'social eating' but in a more upscale manner. The food always exceeds my expectations, and I always walk away happy and with a belly full of delicious food. My favorite is the curries with coconut rice, and the natural tropical juices.Highly recommended, take a friend, your mum, or go for your birthday!

mRzXGJ-BUeCIcODnHo303w.text: Cool setup for a restaurant that accommodates for large and small groups as well as the individual looking for a quick bite.  What I didn't notice till I walked out was they have a row of seats that look out toward the street and on a cool spring day, the windows are open and you can people watch as you enjoy your meal.  For drinks, the guava collins, mango lassi, and ginger tea were all excellent.  The Dolly Pad Mee was very good with just enough kick to it.  The most interesting part of the visit to this restaurant was a trip to the bathroom though... and not in a negative way... they have interesting signs on the male and female bathrooms.  It took me a minute to make an educated guess and I guessed right (a female friend did not)...  Someone googled it later on and the signs make perfect sense after that !

sZ09D-rGvIEKctKRwezzHA.text: Pretty awesome food here, came here with 6 people on a Wednesday night at about 7:30 and the wait was around 15-20 minutes. Not too bad. The decor was nice here and the tables are communal. When we finally got seated, we ordered a few small plates of the Thai Calamari which was awesome (I would definitely recommend ordering that). For my entree I ordered the Pad Thai which was pretty good, I tried some of the green chicken curry which was pretty spicy but it was also very good. I would definitely recommend coming here if you're in the Soho area.

IM1rUmvvW0VwGjsr4nlxUg.text: Always a fan. There was a long line but the wait was only 5-10 minutes, really. Cozy and packed where you have to share a table, but the food was great. My friend enjoyed his crab fried rice and the pad thai was always a good one (though i hate the dried shrimp pieces they use... great flavor but i hate it when i end up chewing on it). Also the mango lassi was delicious!

zD7DY_3ofUavvBNi1SHjmg.text: Still consistently good thai food in Soho. The service, prices and most importantly food are all good. The only critical thing I can think of that may be new is the habit the servers have about asking if you like spicy food. IMO the food is good enough that the kitchen should make it the right way and send it out with correct seasoning and heat level. Ie. Noodles shouldn't be spicy, and a curry should. Let customers do what thais do and add some chopped chili if they want it hotter. If someone goes to a thai restaurant and can't handle a chili in their curry they deserve to get burned. Similarly, if some bumpkin complains that their pad thai or rice doesn't come spicy you should just kick them out of the restaurant.

9nVQy-kNqGXOz6rO1xAjmw.text: The food was reasonably good but the customer service was definitely subpar. When we arrived they pushed us out of the restaurant into the cold to wait. Then they told us it would be a 5 minute wait. Over the next 30 minutes they let several smaller groups in ahead of us (7 people), rather than  saving space for us at one of the tables as parties left (the tables are all shared and seat 11 people).Once inside the tables were crowded and the noise levels were high enough where I couldn't hear conversations from across the table.Several times they took peoples drinks before they were done and without asking (in one case before the food had been served).If you want moderately good Thai food, long waits, crowded conditions, noise and poor service, this place is for you. Otherwise, I'm sure you can find 10 better places within a couple of blocks.

YR2F4BBDd5VQd3OQ0bMuow.text: I went to a different Busaba a few months ago and was pretty disappointed - the portion was small and seemed overpriced compared to other Thai I've had in London, but I have to admit, my most recent experience changed everything!Having been to Thailand a couple months ago I was craving some khao soy, a curry noodle dish from northern Thailand that's known as "Chiang Mia Noodles" in the Busaba menu.  I've never seen in it an American or British Thai restaurant before, so when I came across it I knew I had to try it.  Did it disappoint... NO!  I actually felt like I was back in Chiang Mai while I was eating.  Traditional - check!  Tasty - check!  I'll probably never order anything different at Busaba again, but that's ok by me.

j4Q7HF3-SPWk2k16gk9zkw.text: Tried this place before catching a show and it was perfect. We loved the communal tables, which still afforded us privacy for our meal. The wok chili cashews were delicious, and a perfect way to start into our curries, of which we tried the duck Massaman and the red beef curries. Drink selections were sparse, but they had a Bellini available for cocktail and Singha for beer, so not all bad. Loved it!

wlYlt15_G4QPOgyIPJ3jVg.text: I saw this Resturant on yelp and it had over 200 reviews. It's my last day In London from Florida and I decided to give it a try since I miss my bi-weekly thai  I usually get from the thai Resturant by my house. 1. Decor:It's a very hip artsy style Resturant in an expensive part of town. The lighting is perfect and the decor is beautiful. 2. Service:The service was nearly non existent at worst and lacking at best. Our server was in another galaxy and it took him 20 minutes to bring water and wine. There are several servers for the amount of tables so there is no excuse. I had to remind him several times to get out drinks. He was swift in his responded and had no real personality. (Servers in America actually try to be pleasant for good tips.)3. Food: I ordered thai calamari. I might aswell have ordered sweet caramel toffee calamari because that's what it tasted like. It tasted like a mix between sweet popcorn and toffee. Two things that shouldn't go with calamari. My first main the chilli prawns. They were over salty and it came with way too little prawns, six to be exact and way too much salt.The friendly thai manager apologized for the salty prawns and let me pick something else. I chose the green chicken curry which was sub par and not as good as the cheap thai curry I buy by my house. My Conclusion,This Resturant is over hyped and fancy but the food does not match the decor. The food is nothing special and the service is lacking.

photos.caption: Photo of Busaba Soho - Soho, London, United Kingdom. This is part of the menu

8aPngUlXZO3otMwPvoMieg.text: When we visited London, we stopped in while touring the Piccadilly Circus area. This was the best food we had in the UK. I loved the restaurant itself, great decor.

photos.caption: Photo of Busaba Soho - Soho, London, United Kingdom. Pad Thai
Photo of Busaba Soho - Soho, London, United Kingdom

p6JOrkZO9iR6paEP6PQa9w.text: I adored Busaba, even its big communal tables, rather confused, abnormally slow service and overly heated interior. But still, we had an excellent pumpkin curry, delicious coconut rice and scrumptious other things I can't remember. Not a fan of the "dry" shrimp curry, it was quite dry with a paste-like sauce, but everything else we tried was very good, and the decor/atmosphere is very cozy. I'd go again and again, if my "other" would let me (and if I didn't live elsewhere).

bGQ9WtO03ngvGyct4sqy2Q.text: Cool restaurant and easy going vibes. The food is good but I have had more authentic Thai food for sure. Considering it is a chain, I am not entirely surprised by this. I recommend for someone that is just looking for good trendy food and not necessarily authentic Thai food. Fun fact, my buddy sat next to an Olympic Swimmer named Tom Daley here.

487R0Aeo7YGYrInPCaJWog.text: Busaba is one of my most favourite places to eat in Soho. always busy, you sometimes have to wait for a seat but once seated orders are processed quickly and the food is always very good - I'd recommend the Jungle curry if you like something with a kick or the Swordfish for something lighter.Seating is quite informal, so expect to share a squared table with others unless your party is large enough to fill the space, in which case you'd be advised to book in advance. I love this kind of seating as you can view others foods and interact quite easily without appearing to be nosey.The staff are informative though not always helpful; friends have felt rushed at times though i personally have never had cause to complain. If you're looking for a venue to stay all evening after meal is comlpeted then this may not be for you.Portions are good but do take a side dish or two to ensure that you don't get hungry on the way home. Pricewise it is okay; it's on par with venues like Satsuma nearby though it's not for those just wanting a quick snack.Overall a great venue with some brilliant dishes perfect for a relaxed meal during the evening

tGtnIw2AchJAm8LXlvkiBg.text: This place (and indeed the other restaurants within the chain) really has me torn. On the one hand, the food is genuinely pretty good, but on the other, the set-up and layout is just really uncomfortable. The square tables mean that anymore than two of you and you can't speak to each other comfortably, or avoid what the strangers next to you are talking about. Unless you can take up the whole table (around 10 of you), then you're in for an awkward meal. The staff are occasionally rude, and will either squash you in uncomfortably, or make you wait a lifetime because, despite there being empty seats, the square tables make it difficult to cater for small groups. With regards to the food, the grilled duck is always fantastic. Pink, tender and tasty. The seafood noodles are, again, always a safe bet. The quality of food isn't really in doubt, but the overall experience makes me hesitant to return (although I always seem to end up there at least once every few months).

JED2lSbZYqp2RTlkttecnQ.text: Standard Thai. I popped in once when there wasn't a queue to satisfy my curiosity. Nice meal but none of the tastes blew me away. Love the atmosphere and would go back again!

_o_QPcNxkQCBZ1CaH0U1QQ.text: green chicken curry, steak, calamari and pad thai. those 4 dishes are my favourite in this place! good atmosphere and good food!- worth to queueing to get in!!The best place ever for thai food!

I8ie0PqdgCENPiaxU7Bl-Q.text: Noodle Me! Everything was delicious, and although there was a wait to get a table, it moved quickly.

mK70Qy5jlsEBgEg8D5bFhg.text: The food was amazing, highly recommend the Wing Bean Salad and Thai calamari. Sensational!The only reason I am giving 4 and not 5 stars is because, firstly the waiters couldn't wait to get us out of there, hence bugging us every 2 minutes for our order, when all I wanted to do was sip my wine slowly whilst making my decision. Secondly, I was sitting on the side of a major gangway and I can't tell you how annoying it is to constantly be brushed past by wating staff and the customers alike. This was also to do with the fact we were there in the peak of dinner time.One last gripe, no bookings can be made in advance so you may have to wait but it is definitely worth the wait for the food!

0M4Xiedk_3XRpxLxmlOtrA.text: Fantastic Thai.  Good service.  The Chilli Squid is the best I've had.  Never had a real problem with the queues but if you get there before 12.30 for lunch you can usually pick your seat.

VAgZrPqj56jsGjuMIWtn5w.text: In the Busaba Eathai you can get excellent thai food in a modern and comfortable environment with a very quick service and low prices. The restaurant is well attended and so the noise level is high. Unfortunately I felt a little bit like I was on an assembly line, because of the impersonal service - according to the number of people who are eating there every day. In the restaurant are big tables where you were placed with other people who you don't know, which I don't like that much because I prefer the privacy of an own table with my company. Nevertheless I can recommend this restaurant to everybody who likes thai food and the modern ambience and has no problem with the loud and hectic atmosphere.

gJ7yXP8pfSYJrlKue1QwNg.text: I just love this place; I went there with work last year for the first time and was blown away by the whole experience. You all sit around communal tables, which is odd at first but it's cool, apart from a few seats which are by the windowless window overlooking the streets of Soho. The food, oh my god, was amazing!!! Every time I have eaten there it has been delicious, the staff are very friendly without being annoying or pushy, they are prompt and very professional. It is all very reasonably priced as when you first go in, I thought I could be paying a lot for a meal here. But I was wrong, you can get a large noodle dish for around £7.50. Dim lighting and neutral colours make this eatery a real gem, definitely a place to take that special someone on a date as well as with a group of mates. The only downside, albeit a minor one, is that they don't take bookings, but on the occasions that I have had to queue, even in a long queue, it's only been 10 minutes max.

W0a2YRZxGE7NPOC_KvrC7g.text: Great Thai Restaurant in Soho with communal tables and varied menu. Everything seems to have chili in it which is the only downside for those like me with less tolerance for spice. Londoners still seem fascinated by Thai food and it is often busy with a line out the door, but it usually moves pretty quickly. Not the place to linger though, they move you on pretty sharpish so if you're after a leisurely dinner this is not necessarily the place to go.

ir7uLgcbqjDazCX0rw3ZSg.text: The inside is simple and sleek, with communal seating at large tables.  All of the food is fresh and fast.  Definitely a good place to branch out and experiment with unfamiliar dishes.

9uMUAls9kAq_KnBrHOuDGQ.text: Busaba on Wardour St has to be my favourite (so far) restaurant in London. I love the communal eating set up and the way that you can be jumped right past an entire line of people depending on your group size! Friday and Saturday nights there's always a big queue, but I've never waited longer than 10 or 15 minutes. Great service with food arriving quickly after you order, but no pressure to vacate and make room for the next bunch when you are finished. The food is amazing, with my personal favourites being the Goong Thod Prawns, Thai Calamari and fantastic Sen Chan Phad Thai. Two big thumbs up!

lBuhAp_Cm9b1gV15rJjRhA.text: Best Thai food I've had in London so far hands down.  Be prepared to wait, though.  We went in a large group on a Saturday night, and they don't take reservations, so we stood around in the queue for close to an hour.  Once we got inside, though, the service was very fast, especially considering how crowded it was, and the food was delicious.  The dishes they offer are much more authentic and interesting than the standard pad thai and curries you find at most basic Thai places.  Definitely worth a repeat visit, although next time, I'll try to go at some random off-peak hour.

OaxEqPp4yluAbSUcr_RluA.text: The massaman curry duck alone makes this place worth 5 stars.. I've sampled many a massaman curry dishes but Busaba elevates it to another level.

Iq7JH5KnMPuchfeDFjE0bw.text: What more to say that a delicious explosion of pleasure in my mouth ... mmmm the food is amazing ,,, the duck .. the masaman curry ...mmmmmmmmmmmm.

zGHbsSszddFSwGWrNdjSIA.text: aaaahhh BUSABA how I miss thee. Get the calamari, get the noodles. The curries, in my opinion, are sub-par. But all the other dishes are really innovative and cool. And the vibe is definitely trendy. Then head across the street to the Italian bakery, which is owned by the same people!!

DjNZp9kwlh9175fFmeDxNw.text: 3.5 stars. Food is not bad, and the portion is OK. However, the atmosphere is really loud and crowded. It felt like I was eating in a market. The service was alright, it might be because it's really busy. There's a line. We waited a while to finally get in. We were quite unhappy about being waited for so long since people behind us got in earlier than we do, and they are also bigger parties. Overall, the food does not worth 4 star. It tastes good, but not like WOW kind of good.

NMwRLQlYoemeoZRY1rtvxA.text: hold on to your wine bottle - it might leave the table (un-emptied) as if it earns wings during the meal!!! unbelievable these waitressesss!!!! grrrrr... thank goodness the mgr came over and gave us a free glass.... (BUT that's NOT the point... the point is do NOT clean my alchool if that doesn't go on top of the EMPTY plates too). so RUDE.the food was yummy, greasy, and salty, spicy and hot of the grill, JUST the way i like it! very presentable, adn the service was quick. sure, we had to wait in line for 35 minutes, and sure we had to decide what we were eating/drinking/talking about before we even had a chance to see the interior of the place before reaching the window (let alone the door), but at the end of the day.. err.... night was totally worth it!!!obviously being seated at the communal tables (seating about 12 each) is a great experience, ESPECIALLY if you're a big group (or if you speak a different language, which your communal table compatriots do not understand) and last but not least it's a rewarding experience if you're going to strike up conversation with anyone that is sharing the same munching surface with you.NOT ideal spot if it's a first date, if you are going to break up with someone, or telling them... you're pregnant.very nice, would go back, with maybe a slightly larger group, can't see myself eating at a communal table if i don't have a full schedule of topics to talk about, or if people around me are not ordering weird items.wine - cheapthe duck (grilled) - GETsome weird fish stew thing that was last in the menu and that the waitress suggested, SUCKED... so she should be punished for suggesting that lol.. j/k it's ok..... next time.. will get something ELSE!!!Ori will be BACK!!!

Tyq142OylhE8-Yz4a4ZgUQ.text: We must have caught this place on a slow night- no wait and quick service. The ginger beef was excellent- possibly the best I've ever had. Portion sizes might be considered a little on the small size- but for us it was exactly enough. For the price, I'm not sure you can beat this place for thai.

1B-O0Dsbg53Btrvg6MsgwQ.text: Busaba eat thai reminds me of wagamama but thai style, food is not as good as in some other thai places but is decent for the price... the rushed service is a bit annoying, especially in perspective of the long queue normally to get to the table

L8idUOTjk3bmD9l6x74ZOw.text: You can't go wrong with Busaba.  Be prepared to queue outside for at least a few minutes because it's just that dependably good (and they don't take reservations).  Jungle curry is very spicy, spring rolls are lovely, coconut prawns have a kick and are tasty, coconut rice is always a necessary side, and green curry just can't be beat!

cL_acAy0mW646W3KaCNrIQ.text: There's a reason why Busaba Eathai is a hot topic consistently on Yelp! It's because it freakin rocks... and using the power of words and carefully constructed sentences... I shall illustrate why. I shall firstly justify why this establishment isn't a five star review, so that we all end on a high and we can skip around the room naked. Whilst the queue outside can be a long, dull experience for most I actually quite like it. It gives you a chance to peruse the menu and banter with the person you with. However, if that person has had a long day at work and have only eaten a cracker for lunch, the wait can be one of the most painful experiences as you gaze longingly at the delicious food served to the patrons through the glass windows of destiny. So half a point off for this painful part of the process. The second reason that Busaba doesn't deserve the full fury of my five stars is that, once in and seated, you get the distinct impression they (the staff) would like to to eat and get out as quickly as possible please. Whilst I can appreciate why this is the case, sometimes it is nice to savour your food, company and the thrill that comes with sitting in such close proximity with your fellow diners. However, once you've eaten your food, expect the bill to be on your lap quicker than you can say "Eathai". Having said that though, there is also a reason why I visit this cheeky little number on a frequent basis. Not only is the food superb. I've honestly never had any cause for complaint and despite wanting you out, the staff are super friendly and if you need anything it arrives immediately. Once you enter into the dimly lighted dance floor and are seated on a wooden bench, this is where things take a turn for the better. The food ranges from noodle soups to pan-fried deliciousness to a whole host of awesome curries. My personal favourite is the duck massaman curry with Jasmin rice, which will set you back around 10 English doubloons. The other two dishes I can recommend are the  the Pad Thai, standard favourite at most Thai eateries, and also the pumpkin curry. Expect to pay around the same amount for these as the duck massaman. The other thing is that Busaba is good value for money. There are few places in Soho I have found where the atmosphere, food, service are all equally matched by the top prices.  A meal for two with a bottle of wine will set you back £40.00. If you are in the Soho area Busaba comes highly recommended... Oh and I'm always free if you taking me out for lunch. Sexy.

Dr3Bh_zqQurEqgM6yi77uQ.text: They say food in London is bland? Try again. Busaba Eathai featured an amazing menu, posh, community style seating, and a line running out the door because of its popularity. My three friends and I had great meals and a good laugh as we attempted to translate the bathroom door images. You'll have to visit this fantastic place to know what I mean.

EwvKpt-PljkNVuQPAwBiIw.text: FOOD:there are a lot of thai restaurants in london, and this place is probably one of the better ones out there.  we've been to the store st. and wardour st. locations and have never been unsatisfied with the food.  some of the dishes are your typical thai dishes that are good, but not very memorable.  some of the appetizers we have gotten there, however, are Dee-licious.  SERVICE:hmm... there have been times where we've complained about the slow service (being the first ones to sit at the table, and being the last ones served...) but other times is fine, so i guess that one time was just a mishap.  because of limited seating, they do try to have a quick turnaround, but they do not rush you.  AMBIANCE:communal seating is something that's not very typical in chicago restaurants (except maybe dim sum places), so this was kind of different, but we liked it.  it is always very lively and crowded here, but in a good way.  good for groups and a good time.

P1xNN0bN7JNnWuALkY298w.text: Must go THAI selection restaurant in LONDON and always busy for evenings , great large tables to enjoy all around the restaurant friendly service , quick and very tasty and moderately priced ...we been there at least 3 dinner during our 8 days visit .

G0m4PsuepMaYSVn_bCle6A.text: A little pricey, but the food is FANTASTIC!   A great place to go for vegans and vegetarians. Try their Jasmine-Passion Fruit smoothie and the Veggie Pad Thai! Seating is communal, so it's great for big groups, or for small parties of people that don't mind being social with the neighbors.

ccg6KjMq_8W6Omeh-ZTcHw.text: update 15 June 2010 Received a thoughtfully-written email from Lesley Vaughan of Busaba Eathai's Operations department in response to my Qype review, reassuring me that BE does its best to ensure "you have a great experience while dining at Busaba any time of the day" and that policy is by no means to shoo customers out before they've had a chance to down their Thai calamaris and Chiang Mai noodle soup. So, I'm impressed by their prompt and sincere response, have enough good experiences to let this one go, and am mollified and grateful not to have to carry yet another grudge. And also grateful for their offer of a goodwill voucher, which I'll use the minute it arrives. A *update 2 June 2010 I was totally taken aback the other night, having asked if the kitchen was still open on arrival at about 10.30 and then waited nearly around 20 minutes for the food to arrive, to be told some 15 minutes after it had arrived that the the restaurant was closing and "would we mind finishing up". When I explained that the food had taken a long time and I'd had to remind the staff three times that we were waiting, the response was that "it's normal, when it's this busy, for food to take a little longer, and 'I can give you another 10 minutes, but no more'. Had the waiter who originally shown us the table told us, at the time, that the restaurant would close at, say, 11.15, we would have been able to choose to eat elsewhere. Even though the woman who asked us to hurry did her best to be polite, it's incredibly rude to ask people to either bolt or leave food that they've paid for. Especially when they've already got a mouthful of food. As usual, the food was great, but the evening was spoiled and my guest, an American friend on business, was horrified. Now Rosa's has opened three blocks away, offering better service and value for money, a more intimate dining atmosphere, and is an authentic Thai business, I'll be dining there instead. This is a real shame, because as you can see below, Busaba used to be one of my favourites. Sadly, this often happens when you're so busy you can take customers for granted. Bye bye, Busaba. It was great, for a while. --------- Food here, and I've noticed there's a prompt for tagging the calamari, is terrific, and, for the quality, reasonably priced; 1 1/2 courses each (pricier prawn/monkfish and a calamari to share, Coke/Wine) at 15 per head. If it weren't for the unbelievable, conversation-stopping racket, this place would get my five stars and I'd eat here nightly. A fantastic venue for lunch, when it's quieter, or for grabbing a quick bite with a mate when you've 'ad a few, super. But don't go their after a late afternoon's shop with your mum or aunt, like I did, because conversation will die... Clean lines, bare wood, stone floors, trestle tables and low celings create soundboxes; they look great, but amplify ambient sound. This is a neat trick - if people can't talk, they'll leave after eating. So you keep the tables turning... Interestingly, Wagamama and Cha Cha Moon have the same issues. Coincidence...?

b7l3lv4Hb_9OOOMvo1YJTg.text: I enjoyed the rosebud chicken a lot. It was really tasty and I kind of wasn't expecting it to be. Maybe it's because I am the kind of girl that usually never steps outside the pad thai box. I did at this place and I wasn't disappointed.

vPFtmUoUy507VQHuS0SngA.text: I had to review this place because I love to come here for lunch and it really is worth the trip! I always order the coconut rice which always comes in a pot with a lid on it and is delicious. I also order the chicken satay with extra peanut sauce supplied free of charge. You get 2-3 skewers and the chicken has a really nice flavour. I also like this other dish consisting of meat wrapped in leaves. They put hot sauce and fish sauce on the table. It gets very busy especially in the evening but you can usually get a seat during lunch.I try to get a table near the window and in the summer they open up the shutters straight out on to the seat and watch the people go by whilst I enjoy my lunch. Highly recommended!

SJYsliw8xx1jQGLFaurm4w.text: I am a veteran to both Busaba's in town and I believe this one wins hands down to it's sister in Bird Street. The menus are the same and the food is equally good in both restaurants. I think the atmosphere of this restaurant is much more electric than the 'stuffy, business lunch' that can sometimes be present over on Bird Street. This restaurant adopts a no booking policy which means in busy periods, especially on the weekends, your queuing in the street. A brief shudder may of just come over you but fear not. Your not just queuing in any old street, your queuing in one of the busiest of Soho. Your getting dinner and a show! Where else can you que and wait for your hearty meal whilst watching the fashion elite, the resident transvestites and a massive gay movement of London. Turn to your left and you can start salivating and picking your dinner as fellow diners tuck in. The que usually moves quite quickly and once inside you can enjoy the hustle and bustle of a good Soho eatery. The architects, the fashion students, a few media savvies, one or two celebs, there's always a good mix in here and it's by far the best place in town for a good fill and some people watching.

photos.caption: Photo of Busaba Soho - Soho, London, United Kingdom

6CFGBEukAz91mwxo92HABA.text: I have been to this restaurant three times now; the first time (when it had just opened) was fabulous, the second time was mediocre and the third time convinced me to never go back.  The main issue was food quality--the first time the meat was tender and lean, but by the third time, it was full of fat and gross.  I think they must have cheaped out and switched suppliers.  In any case, you can't fool me with cheaper ingredients, as it was very obvious.  The tiny portions don't help either.  Not spending another dollar at this wannabe Thai fusion joint!

CtFN0jHHQAc7ksZ0CwPU6g.text: This is the original Busaba Eathai; there are now a few others dotted around the West End. The food really is amazing, especially the curry and fish cakes - you can't really fault it. Best of all, the prices are super-low. I would agree with other reviewers that the communal tables are a bit annoying: it is awkward listening to others' conversations and worrying that they are listening to yours. Though maybe I should just lighten up a bit; I guess that's how they keep prices cheap. Also, if you don't want to queue for ages, why not check out one of the other branches, nearGooge St or Selfridges? These are less well known and a bit quieter.

BrlbxwPEztDgvjmyVM48Mg.text: Just ok Thai food in Marylebone.  The jungle curry really mediocre and the prawn fried rice tasted like it came out of the box.  the better dishes were the thai calamari and the spring rolls, which should be far from the best thing on a thai menu.  The ginger beef was also good but overall does not rate as a memorable Thai restaurant.

7XEGq6U0_D-qpSoLAScp_Q.text: Everyone is so glowing about this place - maybe I just didn't get it. The lunch was OK but not stunning. Maybe my tastes are different. I do enjoy Thai but it wasn't really special. I guess Saltyard quality spoiled me and now I want excellent stuff everywhere I go :-) But everyone here loves it so ignore me and go and grab a spot and get yourself some nummy food!

2TC3BPQwFx4-f9y0qSnTQQ.text: Everyone who's ever eaten at Busaba Eathai has raved about it. I've been here once before and though the food was good I honestly didn't think it had anything special over any of the other myriad of Thai restaurants available at London so it has always puzzled me that the lines out the door can often go down the block and around the corner. Which is where it went just after we joined the line. On the night we went to the Wardour Street restaurant at about 7pm the line was fairly reasonable with about ten or so parties before us but it didn't take long before the line behind us had more than quadrupled. People are willing to wait though, a surprisng thing in hurried London, as the food is that good and in all honesty the turnover inside the restaurant is reasonble and the wait not that long - for us it was about half an hour. The restaurant is overwhelmingly buzzy and loud once you get inside. Its not exactly the kind of place which encourages intimate dining and dates. It is also communal style dining so you will definitely be sharing the table with others. Even in a group conversation is difficult and between the four of us we barely said a word at dinner it was that loud. Busaba is known for its speed, reasonable prices and consistent quality. The service was pretty good tonight - friendly and quick (once our waitress turned up.) Food arrived pretty quickly too which was pleasing. With drinks (not including service) the meal was £15 each which isn't too bad for a main meal and shared starters. Surprisingly, or maybe not so surprisingly as its sister chain Wagamama does the same thing, service is not automatically added to the bill which makes a pleasant change. As food goes I guess its pretty good Thai though in all honesty nothing out of the ordinary. The options on the menu are fairly diverse with both typical and not so typical options. Service is also quick and friendly. My only objection is just how loud it gets in the restaurant which makes conversation really difficult. Go for a quick meal option.

2jsTechSGISohPFX0vyL2Q.text: For a quick meal in an informal setting I'll normally take my friends here. The menu is varied, and the food really very good. From all the Thai places I have eaten at, the restaurant certainly had one of the best Pad Thai's I had eaten for a very long time! My friend's Duck curry was also really enjoyable. I'd agree with some of the other reviewers that it's a shame you can't book a table if your group is smaller than 12, but the queue does go down quite quickly.

KmQey8OwKlitCAJ1c6iOwQ.text: There was always a long line at this place and we knew that was a good sign.  The Thai food here is delicious and the ambiance is wonderful when you're with a group of friends.

kJ5ImBBNN3jbVlvWZOhD6A.text: Had dinner with 4 people last weekend to try this place for the first time. Large tables that can fit 12 people so we happened to get talking to a couple of friendly guys. They were saying how much the food had gone downhill, especially the calamari which they'd had to send back to the kitchen twice that eveningNo starters on the menu but plenty of sides instead. Ordered spring rolls, pandan chicken, a salad and prawns; luckily all was quite nice although they sent out 2 prawns by accident. Sent 1 back and they didn't appear on the bill. A few soup, noodle and rice options for mains and some weird curry combinations like duck massaman  very dark, not great. Why not just list all curries and let people choose which meat/vegetarian option they want? Waitress warned that all curries were really, really spicy which put me off venturing to the jungle curry that I had my eye on.Little bit expensive for what you get but would probably go back because of the atmosphere, location. Be aware, you sit on benches and coats are on hangers along the wall so watch what you're wearing/expensive jacket getting nicked.

syPwGDZ3d67AeqOzwjQ-fg.text: Ah, Busaba, my lovely - you are such a tease. The only way to recognize this place is the inevitable, long queue outside - the name board outside the restaurant is in a funky font that looks like jam roly-poly slices stacked vertically.The interior has a noisy, ramen bar-style communal seating arrangement - prepare to be seated cheek-to-cheek!I love their Guava Bellini, a champagne cocktail that's absolutely delicious. Their hot sake Kikumasamune is great if you're in a group.The first time I had their Thai Calamari, I was scarfing it down so eagerly, I almost blinded myself with the chopsticks! I've been here many times since, and have tried everything on the menu - the Pad see ew, Muslim beef curry and the Asparagus fried rice are my favourites.The restrooms are giggle-inducing - the male/female signs are just two ambiguous squiggles, so I waited for someone to exit one of the doors. After half a minute, I gingerly peeked into one, and sure enough, it wasn't the girls'. Eww. The sink extends into both restrooms, and lacks a divider near the bottom, so I could see male hands washing up on the other side - one of them went on to stick into the girls' side with an "ooblegooglegoo!". Real mature, boys.I want to give them a 4.5, because the operation is much like an assembly line, so they have no desserts. Head for Princi, right across the road!

NDiI8k8ToWaMyeCAUOg3bQ.text: We ate here summer of 2010, while traveling in europe.  I'm from LA and LA has best foods of the world.  Didn't think that I'd get even better Thai food in London!!!  Very nice ambience with great food.  The portion isn't that great compare to what we're used to in LA but that's all around Europe.  I'd definitely go back here if I come back to London in the future! :)

FIAlsU7_0SSDW_Fy6X4dJg.text: Delicious Thai food with excellent proximity to the theater district. Very communal feel and great service. The spring rolls are worth the visit alone.

7PMuslx6kdSmPdy3i5TzUA.text: The fried chicken, calamari, and red beef curry are absolutely amazing. If they only served these three dishes, I would probably rate Busaba 5 stars.Contrary to what some of the other reviews have stated, I actually thought the service was sub par both times I've dined here. The restaurant is quite busy and it can be hard to flag down a server. However at the end of the day, it's really delicious and I definitely plan on coming back!

xyIO8jOL6y-Cw9QxwnqRuA.text: It's raining, we're hungry, can you help? Yes. Yes you can.Looking for dinner with EricaU and JulieD we queued up for what we were told would be 15-20 minutes but the line moved quickly. Nice ledge to sit on protected from above. We were in a seated at a shared table for 12ish. Stargazer monkfish green curry £8.30, just okPat king talay: prawn, squid, scallop, Thai pepper, woodear, chili and ginger £ 8.50 was greatChar-grill duck £12.40 is fantasticCalamari is damn nicePad Thai is just noodle to me but the table loved itThe whole evening was a great adventure in food and fun. Good for groups of 2 or 12 to share in good times and great food. I know I had both.

photos.caption: Photo of Busaba Soho - Soho, London, United Kingdom
Photo of Busaba Soho - Soho, London, United Kingdom. Stargazer Monkfish Green Curry
Photo of Busaba Soho - Soho, London, United Kingdom. Pad Thai

Tqs-XnhkIjYyKZL1Omqbvg.text: Another little gem in the middle of SoHo! Typical of all the other restaurants here, the interior is modern and dimly lit-- something I'm definitely not used to seeing in Thai restaurants. Seating here is odd-- there are bar-like seats by the window, and large, square tables filling the rest of the room. The larger tables are communal seating, which I'm not really into. We settled on the pad kwetio, something I've never seen on menus in the states. It was kind of like pad see-ew and pretty damn good. The portion size was pretty generous too. The bf got the red beef curry, which was also good, but a tad small. Overall, everything was reasonably priced and yummy enough to be worth the pretty pence we spent.

AFlW3pwI3LhZj2PQ_KopSQ.text: Knowing what authentic thai tastes like, I'm afraid I cannot recommend Busaba.  My wife said it best, it tastes like a white person cooked the food.  Overly sweet tones, tastes like nothing Asian. Had the duck curry and pad thai. We are coming from Los Angeles,  and every time I visit a major city, I can't help but feel that LA kills every other city in regards to good food and spoils you. The thai restaurants that I stopped going to in LA where I spent equivalent of $16 for a meal, unfortunately, taste better than this place. It sucks I spent equivalent to 43$ for my meal at busaba. No offense to busaba.  Servers were so nice.

OwE35zbV4Xi-09yxqP3F3A.text: Food is pretty good, but not extraordinary here, except the aromatic vegetable curry. That is an excellent curry with pumpkin. I actually don't remember what else we ordered except the pumpkin curry. Oh yeah, the simple papaya salad was just ok; we've had better plenty of places in the UK and US. A very pretty restaurant with posh decor in a fashionable part of London. After a dreary, rainy day visit to Harrod's (skip it, not worth your time), this meal was just the ticket. The pot of green tea was also good.

photos.caption: Photo of Busaba Soho - Soho, London, United Kingdom

Wywk5FMeFLQTgySheE0ZwQ.text: My girlfriend is from Bangkok and we eat Thai food weekly. We ordered a Pad Thai with Chicken and this is the worst pad thai we're ever had. Tasted bland. To be honest, I do not understand why this restaurant has 4 stars... Would not recommend to anyone.

Xn8cAIrItHqVCTEzwxwWmA.text: Expected better from a place rated so highly. Came here for lunch on a Friday, got a seat and within a few minutes the waitress came by asking for my order without welcoming me or introducing me to the place or asking about a drink. I ordered on the spot the Red Curry with beef and Thai Calamari on the side. The red curry came quickly, but the calamari and my drink never showed up. The waitress came by again to ask what I ordered and then still I didn't receive the water or calamari during my meal. Overall terrible service, upon asking for my bill I had to ask them to cancel the calamari, still never got a glass of water. The food had potential. I really enjoyed the spice level and flavor of the curry, but the beef quality was very poor, it was so chewy I could barely swallow. The restaurant didn't even try to right their wrong when the bill came round. I won't be back again.

photos.caption: Photo of Busaba Soho - Soho, London, United Kingdom

Ks15DG5OdhVGHw_19-iSLQ.text: The food is decent. I had the Pad thai, pretty tasty but could have done with more prawns.Not very accommodating either with wanting to sub out tofu for something else. Not a bad place but not the best I've been to and a little surprised given the overall rating.

EkGFjoKjll32U6L1xWV5ig.text: Great food and service. The seating is a little crazy and there are no acoustics other than large open windows to the outside. Nice ambiance!

KpnksrAqkC2PsXUELsuZ4w.text: I love the Busaba Eathai restaurants. The flavours are great, the prices are great, the service is generally pretty good, they are more pleasant to sit in than other restaurants in this price range (like Wagamama, which also has vastly inferior food). I'd really recommend them as a reliable chain where you really get value for your money, although at the same time I wouldn't bother queuing more than 20 minutes to go here...there are other options. On this occasion, My coconut curry was delicious, as was the squid we ordered on the side. I've also had the mom kha chicken in the past and it's tasty too.

BrAJBrbw0w7SWkr-HT6ZDQ.text: I was hoping for more given the high review scores. Our wine looked and tasted cheap, food was nice enough without managing to be outstanding.Given the plethora of other places we walked past on our stroll through Chinatown to get here I think in hindsight I could have probably had more bang for my buck somewhere else. Damn you Yelpers, I thought we were all friends here!

photos.caption: Photo of Busaba Soho - Soho, London, United Kingdom. Phad phak
Photo of Busaba Soho - Soho, London, United Kingdom. Vegetable spring rolls
Photo of Busaba Soho - Soho, London, United Kingdom. Pad Thai jay

VFVM6bCRFCt-JfeKuoMPGg.text: This place has a quaint and enjoyable atmosphere, a break from the chaos of the city. The food is quite good, albeit a bit untraditional. I had the calamari which has a presentation and flavor I've never experienced before, both of which I enjoyed - a lot. I liked it enough to come back four times to have if during my stay in London. The basil, chili, prawn was quite nice too. Simple snd clean. Highly recommended.

tnb-i_2LgZjVRD8j7TWLiw.text: Three stars for the service which made the entire experience kind of mediocre. Three of us went into Busaba and got sat immediately. The girl didn't take our orders for ten minutes!! After that we got our food and in all fairness their food is AMAZING. So we downed the food right away and then we sat for a good 40 minutes because nobody came to take our plates, give us our bill OR refill our water. We asked three times for water and finally after 40 minutes we got water!!! HOW ON EARTH. We honestly debated on just walking out so many times. They would have never known. So service is HORRIBLE. food is great. Weigh your options. But there is a busaba in covenant gardens which is much better with service and the food is obviously the same.

3Dd3VqyifpoiKSOm76svPg.text: Lovely Thai restaurant with a bubbling atmosphere. It gives a very warm feeling especially with the communal tables. The food is always immaculately presented and tastes delicious. I recommend the green curry with chicken - my favourite dish.Can get quite busy in the evenings but it's worth the wait.

5-NNp1ip5E4NJwfpOI-tZw.text: Had several versions of the pad thai and the calamari due to it being their special. Didn't mind the communal seating but I can see how one would depending on group size/arrangement. Calamari was quite tasty but slightly cold. Pad thai was lacking flavor, protein and depth. So disappointed. We had much better at the borough street fair and for half price.

rtGeayymrChK-BIEDUgQIg.text: Good but not great Thai food that's a bit light on the veggies and spices and heavy on the oil. Seating is communal benches, which you may enjoy if you want to re-live your primary school lunch room.

q_eOhHYNXaE6rVFjxMgijg.text: Tonight we had the red curry beef, pad thai (my wife is so adventuresome), ginger beef and green curry beef and fried rice.My red curry beef was delicious.  The beef we incredibly tender and spiced lusciously.  It was spicy and is a great dish to order.  The only dish that I was disappointed with was the fried rice with curry.  My daughter said the beef was very good, but I found the rice to be extremely under-flavored. At this place, you will probably be sitting with other people.  They sit you at a fancy type of picnic table.  But that makes it more interesting because you can strike up a conversation with another group of people.Overall, this is a great place to grab some Thai food.  I give it a low 4 star rating.

p8Ny1TZqYdPsRZhepD-XLQ.text: Be ready to sit with others as there are no private tables ...however service was rather quick and courteous (although, our waiter couldn't tell us how the Mango Lassi was made because, according to her, 'I'm not the Chef' ...anyhoo, the food was good ...altogether, had the Chicken Lollipop, Goong Tohd, Smoked Chicken, Chilli Prawns, and Chicken Breast...and all were good ...will visit again.

tc2oDFiqFhuoRrgsv4nAAw.text: This is fusion southeast Asian food for yuppies/hipsters.  While the food is indeed edible, it's not really Thai food -- it's really a less aromatic, less spicy, shadow of Thai food.It first hit me when I sat at my communal table surrounded by not a single Asian until I entered the door.  Bad sign if there are none of my fellow continent-men in an Asian restaurant... not even the servers. Second sign was that none of the traditional drinks that one would find in a Thai restaurant are on the menu -- there are several overpriced cocktails and fruit juice/tea concoctions.Ordered the som tom, pad kwetio, chili prawns, and a side of chinese broccoli.  Only the som tom approached the aromatic level of true Thai food (i.e., it stunk a little bit). The rest would be considered flavorful if I were to compare it to English cooking, but it was under-spiced compared to true Thai food.  I should be able to smell the seasoning and flavors, but none of that characteristic aroma was present.Overall, this place is a loud hang-out for hip, trendy, non-Asians.  Anyone looking for a true Thai food experience should keep on moving. Oh and there is a noodle place in the area called Pho that is equally as bad.

tu_IdVm7O0MF7D1gFPphdA.text: good food, fast service good price yum yum

FKNvEW7C-takK2ZPxY8SJQ.text: Love, love, love the food! Had a Pad Thai, Pandan chicken and a Jasmine smoothie. The food was delicious and the Jasmine smoothie was a dream! The staff are very helpful and friendly, service is quick and the decor is dark wooden tables surrounded by benches. Large lanterns and golden buddhas decorate the restaurant stylishly.

YlvWCqGE6Rd0mNlaB3cNMA.text: Highly recommended, but be warned it's quite informal ( you share table with others). Good value & great food.

r9ZAFXoDag27AWKhGIR7bQ.text: Love busaba, perfect after a long day shopping and great for a quick bite to eat before I hit the town.me and my friends dine hear reguarly. Love the food its taste great and is good value for money

OUOis2snLJQ_6CAQ5efjJA.text: this is defiently great place to eat good thai food. last week i went there twice. food is awesome, cant go wrong with anything. any one interested in calamari- should definetly try here. love the tai roti(bread) red curry, duck mussalam curry, muslim curry, stir fried cod these are the few dishes should be eaten definetly

RoJN5JwNjeaFYfuyzeAF3A.text: 3.5 stars.  Honestly, for a fusion place, I was veryVERY INCREDIBLY surprised.  For those who know me, I am quite critical of "fusion" food as I find it a cop out used by mediocre chefs to ignore the authenticity of ethnic food.  I'm glad that I came in with low expectations, because Busaba left me quite impressed!1)  Black peppercorn calamari.  Fantastic.  Again, I was apprehensive having learned that this dish was prepared without the tentacles ( guess because that tends to disturb some inexperienced eaters?).  However, the tastes and texture of this dish were phenomenal.  Covered in sesame, spices, and peppers to give just the right kick.2)  Pad thai.  Oh my gosh, I so did not want to order this.  I would never in my life order a Thai staple in a fusion restaurant.  But my friends are stubborn.  I am so glad to have tried this dish because it's given me faith in the quality of all other Busaba dishes.  The dish was not oily, the noodles were not too wet, and the peanut sauce was not grainy!  My main concerns assuaged!  In fact, I would go so far as to say I would order this again.3)  Butternut curry with a side of jasmine rice.  The rice was a bit dry, but this helped in soaking up the curry; so it was well planned.  The butternut was, like everything else, cooked just right; and as it had been marinating in the curry for quite some time, it easily picked up all the best aspects of the curry -- which was delish!  Thick and milky with a spice kick on the finish.  Loved it.   A very simple dish with some great depth in the flavours.4)  Lemongrass tea.  When I ordered hot tea, I was honestly just expecting a run-of-the-mill jasmine blend.  The presentation of this drink is quite lovely, served up in it's own little pot (about 4 servings worth).  The lemongrass was sweet enough that the included honey was not necessary.  And the included cookies were a nice gesture (though a bit dry).Why only 3.5 stars?  -- There are sakes on the drink menu and a few non-thai dishes available for order.  I find this a bit incongruous.  Moreso with the sake, since it doesn't pair well with spicy Thai dishes in the first place.-- The coconut water isn't fresh.  If you're used to fresh coconut milk, this will disappoint you.-- They do not have any desserts here.  Why not?  Given the quality of the dishes I tried, I'd be willing to order mango sticky rice if it were an option.  It's also a Thai staple.  So what gives?  Busaba offers sticky rice and coconut rice (which show up in a lot of Thai desserts), so I was really surprised that they ignore desserts altogether.-- When it came time to pay, we were informed that the debit / credit system had been down for over a few hours (throughout Soho), and all the cash machines in the nearby area were also affected.  This was quite frustrating as our total party did not have enough cash to cover the bill and we were stuck retrying our cards for about 30 minutes until one of them finally went through.  In my opinion, as the machines were down when we first arrived, staff should have informed us of the issue up front to avoid what could have been a very bad situation.Extra info:  -- Group seating, so you share a rather large table with several other parties.  I love this type of style when eating Asian cuisine.  -- Hooks and nooks to store baby strollers, jackets, etc.  Super convenient.-- Plugs, so if you need emergency power for your iPhone, no worries.  ^_^-- Funny symbols for the women's and men's bathrooms.  FYI, the "squatting" one is for women.  Haha.  Doors to the individual stalls are heavy, so don't get confused like me and mistakenly think they are all locked.

YY2XgPr2IxTxxOCq19UXsw.text: The food was decent, but the service was absolutely abysmal -- the worst I've experienced on my trip to the UK. I came alone, and was promptly seated on a Thursday night. It then took literally 15 minutes for a server to take my drink and order. The food came quickly. I ordered a papaya salad and chili prawn stir fry, with white rice on the side. After finishing my meal, it then took 25 minutes -- no joke -- to get the attention of a server to take my plates. After my table was cleared, it was another 10 minutes for the bill. The place had pretty much cleared out by then, so there was no excuse. In total I spent about hour just waiting for the attention of servers.

NGTsufmGEYMg9_uLUMMIIw.text: Ahh, Busaba Soho. You were the location for my first business lunch in London many, many years ago, and you still fill me with joy. Literally. The peppercorn calamari here is amongst the most delicious things on the planet, closely followed by the duck and lamb curries. As I write this I realise it's time to go back already. Gotta go

0n01cZaimLcq4iEwIBcpLQ.text: I don't get it. Every weekend eve there's a huge line out front. The food is good but not line worthy. Highly recommend the calamari "side" (though its more a starter) and the noodles. Avoid the flavourless soups and curries.An extra star for being one of the very few open during the Christmas and New Year holidays.

nXr3ocs5mY5kzK7j1l1qfA.text: Good dinner of pad Thai. I got the one that has egg and is a bit spicier than the base one. But it had NO kick to it all. Interesting flavors. Good but different from what I get in California. No cilantro. No peanuts. But it was good. I didn't think it was phenomenal but this might just be based on what I'm used too.

photos.caption: Photo of Busaba Soho - Soho, London, United Kingdom. Pad Thai - no the base one that is most inexpensive though.

nAyW24U16DOUfuza5Cpxkw.text: First I have to say we went there just to see how is the place...we weren't disappointed! It's a great atmosphere and I like the tables by the window. Food was really great. The option of side dishes was good! Really nice. The only thing which is maybe not the best...you might have to share the big tables with others. It's actually a great opportunity to meet people and have a chat- but for a romantic dinner for two- no!  But in general...a place to go...!

96qzMN1rOT1qRp2hSwIi-g.text: I absolutely adore Busaba, the food, the decor, the service.I keep on going back for more!Well done!

VX7MX9qF6zq3MPW8C2ZYJw.text: This place is such a steal! The quality of the food and the presentation are impeccable. The atmosphere is so memorable and relaxed. Even though you will end up sitting next to strangers, it feels like home!! The tea is really really good, both my friend and I ordered teapots and tried each others. The food is delicious,  everything we ordered was amazing!

rQoWu0ybL4UEgNkDs0HYAw.text: 2.5 StarsBusaba reminds me a little too much of  Wagamama - the food is bland and they like to sqeeze as many people on to a table as humanely possible (and call it 'communal dining). The food is supposed to be Thai, but i would describe it as mixed Asian (meals range from Thai, to Malaysian to fusion).Prices are mid-range for main meals in London (around  £6.50-£12.30) food is brought out speedily, so good for a quick lunch-and-go option however don't expect too much in the way of getting any peronsalised service. Simplistic decor doesn't offer much in the way of a intimarte dining experience, most definately better for groups.

FJJhdaXnZCA_DIXU4FNlIA.text: Wait a minute, is this actually some spicy Thai food in London?  Oh Shit!  It is!I couldn't believe it, bright red thai peppers, nose running, that building burn at the back of my throat and a little bit of fire in my belly as I walked out the door.  Busaba is ready to fulfill a craving I just didn't think could possibly fulfilled in London.  I got the Tom Yum and the broth was spicy delicious.  The whole squid floating in the bowl was shockingly tender and the noodles made it a satisfying start.  Next I searched the menu for Thai Garlic (got that craving, you know) and after asking the waitress to confirm, its true, they only use Thai Garlic in one dish and not with pork, no, its Thai Garlic and Cod.  That seems weird but, whatever,  lets do this.  I could barely taste the thai garlic but damn that was some good cod.  I ate here at 4pm on a Sunday because I'm a weird-o social isolate with no friends in London.  Not a bad place to eat alone at off times, but the hostess for some reason thought it made sense to seat everyone in the place right next to each other and leave a bunch of other tables empty.  So the service is very much a "what is easy for us" mentality, but I'm not gonna hate.

PXX1W_jx7Y4NAUEus-8shw.text: The atmosphere here is great and the food comes really fast. I like the chicken green curry and the pad Thai is pretty good. With a lot of places in London I don't like how many ppl there are but at leat it is big and spacious. If you are willing to sit with strangers during rush hour then it's worth going too.

4Hj1XACDxoRvFKk3l3ds7w.text: There are enough reviews of this place to keep them around. I just want to hit on two things here. First is service. I'm an American and yes, I may be pampered with overly attentive service and unnecessary amounts of food while dining but service here was outstanding for all the wrong reasons. I was with large party and our service was just slow and and the waitstaff inattentive. We had to hail our waiter several times because our drinks needed attention and the food just came out at different times. But the food was glorious. It was a huge break from the bland tasteless food our party had been subjected to while working out near Windsor. I loved my black pepper ostrich and the consensus around the table seemed to reflect that the food was pretty good. I thought the portions were just right but some at the table thought that the portions could have been bigger. If anything, I would recommend using the bathrooms here. The symbols for the bathroom are UHMAYZING! Just stand there and reflect on the simple beauty and hilarity of it all. I'm a little slow sometimes. I'm not gonna lie it took me longer than normal to figure out which symbol represented the designated area. I'll leave you with a pic. But if you are on that side of town I would recommend this place for a decent plate of food.

VtkIi0W2fDOQbZnRiXeG3A.text: Very good Thai food and we have our share of thai food all over the world. The noise volume is very high and gets very hot and stuffy. The wait is not bad. If you are about the food then come here. But if you expect service and ambiance, then this place is not for you.

P-siShrbFsoFnv3zIcEFyg.text: I didn't know what to expect when trying this restaurant since I've been to many good Thai food places in SF. I don't write many reviews but I had to for this one. It's very good Thai food based on what I've tried: Starters: chicken satay, calamari. Dinner:  fried chicken lemongrass, ginger beef, vegetables. Every bit was excellent. The line outside was long but the churn wasn't so bad.

VbXLIAlsir8NJB8fRKRDgg.text: Good solid noodle place, nice atmosphere

5m-rq0-8YmCM8Jam5ORRoA.text: I was walking by towards Soho when my nose and neck yanked me backwards into the restaurant to explore.  Cute!1. Food: delicious!  Friends and I had the grilled calamari, pad thai, and chicken dish.  Despite being full, we polished everything off.  Most delectable calamari I've ever had, and that pad thai was delicious too!  Also got the coconut water with lychee juice, and the carrot orange coconut juice.  Very interesting combinations and the ingredients worked well together.2. Service: it was rather busy that night, and the waiters were stretched tightly.3. Atmosphere: casual, dim, laid back and relaxed.  Food around square cafeteria tables.  Loud din.

XCnfCnsktu4cBKQkc6cczg.text: This is a fabulous Thai with fantastic and interesting fare. It is not your plain old everyday curries and noodles... there is artistry to this food and it's so fab, in fact, I had two dishes (and appitizers). Yeah, I'm a cow, but in my defense, the portions are not as large as what I am used to in America. Seating is community style and it certainly makes for fascinating people watching. I'm not much of an oberver of random crowd behaviors, but Mark, my dinner companion who introduce me to this deliciousness, was absolutely fascinated. I wished I remembered what I had there, but alas I did not... I blame the fact that just prior to entering the establishment, I had tripped over a bike that had been tipped over and ended up on my arse in the most fantastical 10 point landing. The hostess was very concerned for my well being as was the nearly 50 some odd patrons who saw my performance through the huge glass windows (similar to a big screen plasma). What can I say?
