Nothing, other than that I'm a clutz and I'm glad I was able to provide some dinner entertainment. Will go back, despite the trauma.

JDyUYNRGsVsPwymPyRJOLw.text: My quest to find a very good and decent priced thai restaurant in London it has been proving to be very difficult. Thais that are not thai, chinese restaurant doing thai food, fusion-more-or-less-like-thai-but-believe-me-not. I found almost everything, but not the perfect thai. (Like the one in my hometown where they served food decorated with real flowers...aww)Just to be clear, Busaba Eathai is NOT the perfect thai. But is the thai you can visit almost regularly in the meanwhile your search for the perfect thai continues. The interior is dimly lit but the atmosphere is relaxed and somewhat refined. The menu is not huge but full of interesting dishes. Beverages are very original and well blended. I had a plate of chicken satay (one of my favourites thai foods) and it was well presented and well cooked. The peanut sauce was not so peanuty as I would loved it to be but it was tasty.Then I tried some ginger ostrich and the meat was very tender and very well seasoned with ginger.Also the Pat Tai Jay (wok rice noodles with vegetables) were well presented and tasty (I wasn't to impressed by the oily and spare tofu and the very very light aftertaste of burnt that apparently is so common everywhere except my fav thai in my hometown)We also tried the so famous calamari and they have held well their reputation, they were tasty and tender. At the end the bill was just right. So what can I say more about Busaba? That is really an OK place, if you wanna try it I don't think you will be disappointed.

NRYOZjsGHyjCR2Xa9PgyFA.text: I am currently on business in London, and have been deprived of Thai food after eating Swiss cuisine for months. It is almost impossible to find an affordable quality Thai restaurant in the French part of Switzerland.  I don't remember ever eating at the same restaurant 2 nights in a row.  Well I can now say I have done that. I had to, after seeing all the other yummy dishes I wanted to try, and having missed Thai food for so long. Definitely come before 7:30pm. Even during the week the place gets crowded starting soon after 7:15pm.  The atmosphere is great, service good, and the prices are reasonable. The spices were perfect, and the tea was INCREDIBLE!  You can't pass up the tea.  Both flavors are great, but my favorite was the ginger.  Would I go back for a 3rd night, yes, but I have to get some Indian food before I leave, as Switzerland is also devoid of good Indian food.

ef_ajGhuZDYfCRyg8-w7Pg.text: What can I say about Busaba Eathai.  Well let's start with the do nots.Do not go here if you can't want to wait to be seatedDo not go here if you want to sit at your own tableDo not go here if you want some time for a quiet conversationBut if you do want good, reasonably priced, very consistent Thai food in Soho this is your place The first time I came to London a few years ago I asked several friends where to eat and all of them said Busaba Eathai, and they were right.  Every time I come to London, I make time for a mealThe food is consistently good, and many of the dishes have a spicy kick to them.  I think the spicy green rice and the Mussman duck curry are the best dishes they have, but I have liked all of the dishes I have tried.  The atmosphere is also different from what you would expect in most places.  The tables are big and different parties are seated together.   Although I don't generally talk with other parties it gives you an oddly social feel.  It is also busy enough that people generally eat pretty quickly and don't hang around.  I don't feel rushed, but I also don't want to hang out like I do in some other places.  I wouldn't rank it as the best Thai food I have ever had, but it is high on my list.  If you are in London and looking for a good meal, it is worth a stop.

JE-xS1S2TVo32mfcDesblw.text: Local chain restaurant that's 100% yummy.  I ordered the tom yum soup and curry - it was delicious and hit the spot after a full day of sight seeing London.  It's not completely authentic, not super fast food, but for what the restaurant is trying to be - a trendy, hip scene with thai influence - it's definitely hit its mark.  If you're looking for some quick, delicious food, no reservations needed kind of place, this is it.

wtBIT0WHpuF4jb0TGbWiFQ.text: Great place - the food was lovely and the place had a wonderful vibe. I had a soft crab rice dish with spring rolls and prawn crackers. My friend had a chicken curry dish, which was also nice. They have a personal Thai beer which goes brilliantly with the dish.

photos.caption: Photo of Busaba Soho - Soho, London, United Kingdom

G04SX1cJxEJeNN-vnp9TNQ.text: The food was great. I had soft shell crab and Pad Kwetio. The Pad Kwetio only had 3 pieces of shrimp. This is not substantial. Another person I was with got the same amount of shrimp so it was intentional. The atmosphere is very nice. They have large tables to seat about 9 people so you get seated with other groups. That concept is okay for me but might be awkward for some.

p8hW97zFU4uAJoCv5hfMpg.text: This is the bus you need to hop on in order to get to FLAVOUR TOWN.the crab rice? Omg! I want to die and be buried in it. The flavours are divine.... Considering I had a pet crab, I'd order this 1876654433 times over. I did feel guilty. RIP Mr.crab.I picked from the pre-theatre menus, which was a side and a main for £9.90, it was a complete bargain! I almost slapped the waiter when I found out how cheap it was. I picked the squid as a side, it was sweet and savoury, delicious.I'd recommend this place, you get great tastes for a decent price .

photos.caption: Photo of Busaba Soho - Soho, London, United Kingdom. The glorious crab rice!

mAUIi6fQRIFmfD3Npz3bqw.text: I have been here a few times, the food is pretty good (I like their use of more exotic Thai ingredients), however I often find the serving sizes a bit on the small side and the service a bit slow. Try the calamari starter.

-CMrZwJoHUPNJaWWapZLfQ.text: Fantastic food, location, with friendly and good service.  My goto spot when I am in London every time.

s25TtZbSsQ9XDzlGk3pq2Q.text: My friend and I really fancied some quick Thai food so popped in here between cocktail bars. We were seated quickly (be-warned the tables are sharing tables only so you are sat on a corner of a table of 8) however once sat were left waiting quite a long time to have our order taken. We both went for a Pad Thai and boy did it come quickly. Unfortunately it was COLD - not luke warm but FREEZING. We ate until we could grab a waiter, which also took quite a while, and told them it was cold. They took it away immediately with an apology and brought out a hot hot hot replacement quick enough so I have to give them some stars for the way they dealt with it. It isn't a bad Pad Thai but I have had better - not worth the aggro! It then took forever to get hold of someone to pay the bill. When we did get hold of them we then had to wait for it to be brought over and they put service charge on! Bloody cheek!

photos.caption: Photo of Busaba Soho - Soho, London, United Kingdom. #colourblast spring rolls
Photo of Busaba Soho - Soho, London, United Kingdom. Chicken pad Thai - luke warm!

GCLxQlvrJN0UB7J8IHRAGQ.text: The taste is not very good. Chicken Satay is much worse that I ate in other restaurants. The Tom Yum Goong is soooo sour that has no other flavor in it. Never order it!

cNDFQCyfuDblGSx1BG-iuQ.text: We came here from the high yelp reviews. There was a long line but it moved quite quickly and it wasn't bad to stand outside. We were both in the mood for some Thai food and were surprised with what we found!The people were working hard and it was very busy. They were really good about properly seating a lot of people in an area. We shared a table with a ton of people but the seating was such a way that it still felt very private. We had the chicken satay for an appetizer and it was perfect. The chicken was juicy and had a lovely flavor to it. Next came the asparagus fried rice with green curry and jungle curry. We were warned that the jungle curry was very spicy, but it turned out that the green curry was even spicier! I wasn't a fan of the green curry at all. I love green curry but this one just wasn't working with me, the spice was too strong and I couldn't enjoy it! But the asparagus fried rice was soooooo good! The dried tomatoes in it really hit the spot. Oh gosh, after I tried it I had wished I just ordered the chicken satay with the fried rice. So, all in all it was a great experience, very affordable and enough food. They didn't give us water, but I guess that's normal if you don't ask for it. My drink was tasty- Guava Bellini, and for the most part the food was very very good. The service was also top notch! You go busaba Eathai! I'd for sure come here again. German timeIch denke dieses Restaurant is am populaersten in London! Um 8:30 Uhr sind mein Freund und ich hier gehen. Es war eine grosse warte schlange aber war es schnell. Das essen war sehr gut aber war der grun curry ein bisschien zu scharf fur mich. Der Kellner war sehr schnell und freundlich. Die Preis ist gunstig und ich bin zufrieden!

photos.caption: Photo of Busaba Soho - Soho, London, United Kingdom. Chicken satay appetizer?
Photo of Busaba Soho - Soho, London, United Kingdom. Green curry

qIicca8EOqobNXfi20HoSQ.text: Granted, I was beginning to be sick with a stomach bug, so in no mood to enjoy food. Having said that, I was still disappointed with this place after hearing so many rave reviews. We ordered a morning glory to share and I ordered a seafood pad thai for myself. The morning glory was amazing -- I loved every bit of it including the freshness and the sauce. I appreciated my pad thai less. It was solid, but not much different from what you'd get elsewhere.Service was solid. We were seated in the far corner, so a bit off the servers' radar at times, but when serving, they were kind and prompt. Ambience was also good. More of a food court/chain feel than had expected, but relatively posh nonetheless. Overall, I might give it another try sometime but for now, three stars.

gxE9Qe0-4Fsy3Rqdu544qA.text: Delicious Thai at prices that don't bite. A very informal dining place with shared tables & delicious drinks. The pomegranate & elder-flower soft drink was a perfect way to start the meal on a hot summer evening. The southern fish curry was a semi-spicy aromatic curry with fresh tilapia that went well with the white rice. Really enjoyed it. Also tried the beef curry and crab fried rice - the curry was excellent, but the fried rice was nothing special. Can get really crowded in the evenings, but the line movies quickly (yes, there's a line!). The service was quick, easy and efficient.

H0NyioWCTYQBkJtfFnvsXQ.text: The portions have gotten way smaller than before. This place knows it's popular, so they give smaller portions and less dress meats, and no one complains, because it's "trendy."

eAW4j3eG2gpHkUJsadj_mw.text: It was Christmas eve in London and No places were open. We came across Busaba and thought to try it. (LOVE thai food) so expectations are there. The place was nice and cozy, all the tables were shared (not the biggest fan but not bad). The servers didn't seem properly trained but they were all super friendly and nice. The food was good. Definitely above average. I would definitely come back if I were in the area but not sure about going out of my way for it.

XihKh_9DLfcngogQSa0f_w.text: The chic decor is a win, but the food could be a bit better. I found most things to be on the blander side, and maybe that's necessary to cater to a UK palate, but it was a bit of a letdown for this Asian gal. The Chili Prawn Fried Rice (shiitake mushrooms, lime with pickled morning glory) lacked spicy seasonings to balance out the citrus. I also tried some of the curries (forget which ones) and definitely felt they were more cream than anything else.

XacvSEDLr3S3Yo9f33EdFQ.text: Great service, no ridiculous wait times, the recommendations are spot on. Skip the Mango Lassi though - it tastes like mango juice mixed with yogurt! Go for the house specialty Pad Thai and the fried rice is top notch too. A place in Central London that won't break the bank, and will also fill you up - win-win!

photos.caption: Photo of Busaba Soho - Soho, London, United Kingdom. Ordering so many starters. Loved the fish cakes. Order the rainbow! #colourblast

GRh1nmNWMINlXGSKCq_Veg.text: Second best meal I had on my trip. I recommend the calamari and the green curry.  You will not be disappointed.  Service is a bit slow. No line / queue if arriving early for dinner. Otherwise expect a long one.

Ux5HfKuav8TumwFmOKNh4Q.text: Think about the drab, flavorless stereotype of British food, and then think about it's exact opposite and you'd get Busaba.  This place is awesome - they have a lot of locations, which is usually a red flag for me, but the fact that more areas of the city get to experience its awesomeness is fine with me.  I've been to the Soho location and the Leicester Square location.  Which one is better?  It's a Thai.BOOM.  Nailed it.The prices are super reasonable, the wait to get seated usually isn't crazy, and the service is efficient and friendly.  If you're an American, don't be lazy and get the pad thai that you always get at every Thai restaurant you've ever visited - go for the chicken butternut squash stir fry and the duck curry.  You're welcome.Food: 4/5Value: 5/5Service: 4/5Atmosphere: 4/5

K14CjAEP00TfEhkX53uCuw.text: We arrived late to town and were hoping we could find something before most places closed.  Our cabbie suggested Busaba as the clock was running down so we took a shot.  As expected the crowd was thinning, made up of a mix of locals and out-of-towners.  The food was really good and met or exceeded that of most of the many Thai places we know in the US.  We had a wonderful avocado salad, very solid shrimp pad thai, soup, and a squash-based dish that we had not experienced before.  I would not choose this place for a Thai cultural immersion dining experience-it's nothing like that.  But anyone can walk in here and feel very comfortable and find something they will like on the menu.  The restaurant was fun, the food quite good, and the staff was very attentive. We got back to our hotel very happy that we had dodged our fear of having to raid the minibar for sustenance and felt like we had salvaged the little time we had to gain at least part of a night out in London..

AlEfnCKk5kpCA4ADDimxCg.text: Great food, and accommodated my family with reliability short notice. What more could you ask for?

iEz-b-yXBKQxpj2PEV09mg.text: Stopped by on our first night in town.   Tried to get a screwdriver and the staff just stared at me.   They have a bartender but he only makes the crappy sugar drinks on the menu.  No screwdriver or other standard cocktail.   Ordered the chicken satay which was dry and tasteless and the egg fried Rice which I took two bites and pushed it away.   Save yourself a couple of hours and a lot of frustration and walk on by.

qMMfoYv3x9LYMVSPAyUcWQ.text: Had lunch here on Monday. the phad Thai with crab meat & papaya along with calamari. Within a few hours, I had symptoms of Gastroenteritis. Advice from a GP confirmed these systems most likely came from contaminated food. Googling this told me that someone had handled the food I ate and clearly did not wash their hands properly, hence there was probably traces of faeces with contaminated the food vile. I was bedridden for over a day and vow never to eat at busaba eathai ever again.

CmnSwKZyTtwkBXzx8uv_Qg.text: From the decor to the duck on my plate...this place spoke to me on a number of levels. The staff are courteous and I usually go during not so busy times as to avoid the crowds and thus able to enjoy the atmosphere and calm down this little side street in Soho. The duck is just wonderful as are a number of their starters, along with a not so bad wine list. A great place for a relaxing break from the noise just a few streets over and a good vibe to enjoy with friends.

CjISevMboCVrhL-YF6Hsjw.text: This was my go-to restaurant for a fun cheap meal whilst living in London.  The tables are great for large groups and the food is delicious.Highly recommend!!

2zBcpTm3DbuggfjPlQfCVw.text: No people here, workers or guests that I saw. What Thai restaurant does not have Thai iced tea? A tourist spot, definitely not a place for authentic Thai food. Food was just okay but definitely not authentic at all. King of Thai I. California is a million times better. Haven't tried any other Thai places in London yet so I do not have anything else to compare it to.

2BPpT0RcDsQXw7jLZWj0wA.text: I have been going to Busaba for a few years and it is generally pretty good. The Thai food is about average by Australian standards but pretty good for Soho. The menu is very restricted and the dishes are all safe Thai bets. Recently however (Spring 2011) the portion sizes have gotten a lot smaller and on my last trip two dishes out of our five were disappointingly cold. The staff are very friendly and efficient but I don't think some of them really understand English. They asked three times if everything was alright and were told three times that the dishes were cold, but they just smiled and nodded and walked away. It is still a safe bet for a quick meal if you are out in Soho but I am not sure if it is really worth queuing for any more.

AAjImhpAvjryHiCAKNcqNA.text: Very nice and authentic Thai food in Soho. Prices are slightly too high, F&B service very friendly. The arrangement of the tables is quite interesting: either you share a big square table with others or you take your seat at the window bar.

TP8SOabMbpkRaqtDZBMyCA.text: Hands down the best meal of the week. Maybe a Top 5 meal of life. Calimari, best I've ever had.Awesome fried prawns.Pad Thai with shrimp and crabmeat. wow.Giant bottle of Sirrachia at the center of the table.Top it off with a crisp Singha.The line was way too long for a Saturday night so we came back on Sunday and walked right in. The place is dimly lit, and probably plays some cool music, but I couldn't hear it because the conversation level is up there. Simple, delicious, no too pretentious.

2b1H4Z-dL_F35eBb6hk1HQ.text: I heart Busaba!The Soho restaurant is the original Busaba and the best for people watching. The best time to go is for a late lunch during the week or weekend. You'll avoid the (wrap-around-the-block) queue that is a permanent fixture after 7pm. I have been eating here at least once a week since it opened 10 years ago (Dang! how much money must I have spent). I have tried everything on the menu (honest troof). I love initiating Busaba virgins and watching as they become enlightened by the wonders taking place in their mouth. Listed below is a guaranteed palette pleasing fail-safe meal for the uninitiated.Sides (they don't call them starters)- Thai Calamari (People walk out of the restaurant if this isn't on the menu, it's that good)- Goong Tohd (Shrimp in batter - yeah I know that's nothing special but it's the mango dip that comes with it that will blow you away!)Noodles- Pad kwetio (If you're in the mood for noodles and like spice)- Rose apple stir-fry, Pat king talay or Chilli prawn stir-fry (all very easy on the tongue. Eat with Jasmine Rice)Curries- Green chicken curry, Jungle curry (Very spicy!), Muslim beef curry or Southern curry (the lamb in the latter can sometimes be a bit fatty).- The curries are best with Coconut or sticky rice.Drinks (Sorry I'm thorough!)- Homemade lemonade (So good you'll wish all swimming pools were filled with this)- Boylan cherry soda (nostalgic and very nice)Stay away from the following dishes: Prawn and yellow curry stir-fry, Fish cakes and Som tam salad. I don't know why they're still on the menu. They used to do a duck salad that was divine. Please ask your server to bring it back. Maybe if enough people ask for it they'll re-instate it.SIT, ORDER, ENJOY!

kGioJn_xobCgLwDI51mnJA.text: My goodness, this has to be one of my new found favourite restaurants in London. Thai food at its absolute best! I went a few nights ago and sampled the green curry and jasmine rice which was the best Thai meal I have ever tasted. The restaurant has a casual vibe and is perfect for grabbing a seat by the window and eating your meal whilst watching the people of Soho pass by. No one will notice if you are on your own as the seating layout makes it easy to do this without feeling isolated in that 'table for one' kind of manner.The best thing about the place (aside from the food of course), is the price. So cheap! They have really got the concept of serving great food at great prices right. You will leave very fulfilled!

wY4iUuZR-jIMfHpbPghseg.text: Everything is delicious, the price is inexpensive, i am a proud regular, its just simply fantastic!

GdNSODnkbAdRE5Q_X31Ydw.text: We popped in here at 11pm for a late apres-movie dinner. We were seated at once and told to order immediately as the kitchen was closing. No sooner had we sat down there was a waiter at our elbows asking for our order! The staff were very friendly, even though we had come in very late. The tables are large and they squeeze you in where there's space, but it still manages to retain a fairly intimate atmosphere. The decor is chic and modern, with small, golden buddahs lined around the ceiling shelf and large windows that allow you to watch the world go by. When the food arrived (quickly) it was delicious, with rich flavours and fresh ingredients. I had the chicken and butternut squash stir-fry which had dried chillis and cashew nuts. All round good place, suitable for any party from friends and family to a date, and reasonably priced too! I'd go again.

EssdaxmalREPJcHjOwf6aQ.text: This is a pretty hoppin place that drew a big crowd the night we were in.   Fortunately we got seated just before the line started extending out the door and down the block.  While not an authentic kind of food place, it gets the fusion thing right and the prices are great for London.  The teas were yummy and the calamari was amazing.  It's definitely the thing to order here.  You can thank me later.

gzex2uWuDOAim2L0E6ZpQw.text: Busaba is one of my favourite eats in London. I've yet to find a better place with a pad thai to rival and there is a lot of choice in London! I think the portions can be quite generous, depending on what you are eating, and the chicken satay comes with thick chunks of breast meat and nice substantial dipping sauce. There are some things can be a bit hit and miss, like the jungle curry, which the waiter said was 'rustic', which basically meant, lots of fat and gristle on the meat and some things like the ginger beef that are just divine. The Thai green curry could be spicer, but it could just be me and my liking for things hot, and the jasmine smoothie used to be my favourite drink there, but they seems to have altered the recipe a bit and it's more watery.If it's your first time, you can't go wrong with a stir-fried dish as they are all pretty nice, I think I've tried 80% of the menu, so it's a more than informed opinion though the rose-apple one is one you might steer clear of.. it's a bit weird having apple in a stir-fry! I like the solid wood and the windows that open out unto the street and if the Busaba in Soho is crowded.. don't bother queueing, there is one just off Oxford Street near Gap and it's just as nice and a bigger restaurant. I have never had to queue for very long if ever there.

VseRpA4ewXb68YYCHuD2_A.text: The pad Thai was great with a balanced flavor and  it was not too oily.  The green vegetable curry was good but beware as it is SPICY!  I love spicy food but this was pretty hot!  Their fried chicken was different and I would pass on it.  Oh, and the green papaya salad is also good but very SPICY!

aYRLdAmSYOx6I66Idt0UXQ.text: Greetings from Germany. I have travelled to london a couple of time and each time I would go and eat at busaba. I just love the fresh and modern way asian food is served and not to forget the design concept is also really cool. Its rare to find concept restaurants with good prices in Germany. So, a definite RECOMMEND!

ooGBsEyaw5EcFsr_HM1q6Q.text: The wifey and I hit this place up while strolling through Soho...so glad we did!  The atmosphere was trendy Asian and the food was really good.  Go for the calamari...it was a standout dish...very unique and tasty!

R4P1BLsro49WqjTJujZhYA.text: One last check in and review from our recent trip to London. I really liked this place, good food, fun atmosphere. My wife says the Pad Thai is not as good as her favorite, Tommy's in Denver, but a close second. check out the loo, if you have a few drinks it may be tough to figure which is men's vs women's.

if7ilU5NMInHi5E446Q5Cw.text: Busaba Eathai is an extremely popular Thai restuarant in Soho, sometimes too popular. If you turn up close to, or on a weekend, you will be waiting a long time in the queue. Once I found myself so far back in the queue that I eventually realised that I was standing in the smokers section of the pub next door - the two groups had merged. Needless to say, I got back into the correct queue. Once you are in the restaurant I would advise you to choose fast and order quick because your waiter will be rushed off his or her feet, and you are not ready to order, you may not see service again for a while. Also bare in mind that this is a very noisy place, and you have to practically shout to hear yourself or your dinner companions. If you are going for safe bets, the green, red or yellow curries are substantial and very tasty. A great side is the crispy squid, which was far larger than I would have expected and could almost have been a main. The chicken parcels which come on banana leaves are also very good.Desserts are kind of left out on this menu, but people don't come here looking for puddings - usually this place is a pit stop en route to Soho watering holes. A little interesting side note - I met a lady in the toilets who used to work here and she said that the food was marginally better in the Russell Street branch.

yw-TKg0l7cnUDiyQbmtTBA.text: I didn't think much of Thai food before eating here yesterday! I had ginger Ostrich.....'twas absolutely gorgeous! would highly recommend this place! very good food for pretty cheap really!!! mmmmm

8U-v2IqkhZr4l90s1Xhm0Q.text: Excellent and tasty Thai food that offers good value for money. The inside has a canteen style seating arrangement. It was really busy when we went and it had a noisy and lively atmosphere. The staff were very friendly and happy to provide recommendations. Be warned, they do not take reservations and on the Friday evening by the time we left there was a queue outside of people waiting for a table. I love Thai food and will definitely be heading back.

NvtzRVIEa8WqkDhiBozZTw.text: Some of the best Thai in central London I think... or at least some of the best thai in great surroundings. It's open late too. I like to take people here who haven't experienced it before and feel smug. Like I've let them on to one of the worst kept secrets in London!Can't really add to the positive remarks aleady made but I will echo that the long queue and the sometimes less than spacious canteen style eating are the only downsides for me. But their restaurant just off TCR is usually less busy and more spacious though.You need to have the thai calimari. Incredible.

rMpTUPIEA6aIVtAYCJb5Yg.text: love love love love love love everything about this place (and miss it dearly!). next time i'm in london, i'll be happily standing in line to eat here. everything is good (i've tried it all)do not miss the black-pepper calamari. it's out of this world.

M42N-JdvpmEPWbNUFjSfpA.text: Totally aaaight. Fast & not particular courteous service, some awesome, some bog-standard food. Inexpensive.The job here is turning tables, which they do well. Can be hard to hear over the din (it's a lot of people and all hard, slick, solid surfaces)I wouldn't queue -- long -- but if I was in the hood and the Q was short, well... I'd go.

HlDMeEuKjoZZ8pNRi9m2_g.text: After three months without Thai food, it was becoming hard to ignore my cravings, so my friends and I decided to come here when we found ourselves too tired to forage for food in our flats after travelling all weekend.We arrived around 9 pm, and even though it was Easter Sunday, the place was packed. We waited in the line outside for about 20 minutes before they ushered us in and seated us at a table with two other groups. The service was quick and friendly, and we got our food within another 20 minutes (thought we were so hungry that it seemed like 20 hours). I ordered the chicken noodle dish with Chinese broccoli. It wasn't what I was expecting -- the noodles were very thin and dry -- but it was delicious. My friends' dishes were also amazing, and I think I liked the beef noodle soup dish the most. Make sure you try the iced green tea -- it comes in a packaged bottle, but it goes perfectly with Thai food. I'll definitely be back if I'm hit with another Thai food craving before I leave London.

GLL7CvSSIGR2jcJEc80zGw.text: With a queue that always seems to rival Floridita, and a set up that reads like an upscale Wagamama, I wasn't sure what to expect. Service was fast and friendly, the (s) on the menu that warned me of spice was half-correct...well, it wasn't a scale of chilies, just a heads up, and I asked if it was one of those British incantations of the word spice, or if it actually harbored some kind of chili, it did, but my face wasn't melting.  Still, quite nice to get something returned with an (s) that isn't sweet. And they made a calamari that I actually liked, not those generic onion ring-looking things. I left feeling like I was about to explode.  In the best way possible. And the queue moves pretty quickly, so don't be turned off by it!

T1NmgkaM9WUPh3m0fF1PyA.text: Great location in the heart of Soho, with very good Thai modern food and a good and casual atmosphere. It is the only place in London where there is always a huge queue waiting to enter outside, so you can wait for around 20-30min outside easily. Once you get it, you are placed on any table where there are seats, and most likely you will be sharing the food with strangers, unless you get one of the seats that face the outside window. This is one of the aspects (sharing your table with strangers) that people find charming about this place, and other people really dislike. The food is great, even if you are not so much into exotic food, so I would always give it a try. It is different, and I do recommend it.

c2uoswkMtIWA2yzgwBdUVg.text: The food here is delicious.  Perhaps some of the dishes are £1 or £2 extra than I would normally want to pay for Thai food per dish, but it is not unreasonable, given the quality, the central London location and the lovely restaurant itself.I like the clean, modern, airy feel to the place.  I like the big wooden benches and the staff uniforms (they wear long black aprons round their waists).On my last visit I shared a bottle of sake, chicken wrapped in pandan leaf (really succulent and tasty), char-grilled tamarind duck with broccoli and papaya salad.  Everything was fresh and delicious and came in good portion sizes.For overall everything, this place is a winner!

che8bHiQ5iRohe_uFBEG0g.text: This place is probably best described as the Thai equivalent of Wagamama. The food was tasty and the service was quick and efficient. Good recommendation for a reasonably priced mid week meal

NZqBwqEhdsNJlcGZ5KScww.text: Love this place. There's no reservations, so on a Friday night you might want to grab a beer from the local Offy before you join the queue. Tables are shared if you're in a group of 3 or more, or if it's just a couple of you you should be seated by the window. It's great watching people walk by, staring at your food.We've been to Thailand and the food is the most genuine I've ever tasted. Service is great and we're always shown just the right amount of attention by the waiters.It's dimly lit inside so is very cosy, but can get loud. The prices are fine, we've never paid more than £40 for a meal and cocktails. Oh, and you have to nick the orange pens, they're the ultimate trophy.

azZzjAcJhZAddS_Yeegprw.text: This place is AWESOME. Better then any Thai food I've ever had in Thailand or the States! The service was pleasant, venue itself was very well designed - simple, clean lines and chic communal wood tables which I simply adored (both the communal part and the gorgeous tables). The scents as you walk through the door are of yummy spices and light amber... d'lish.Another added bonus Busaba was that it wasn't insanely pricey - I'm speaking as an American having gone there when the dollar/pound conversion was nearly 2 to 1, so it was hard to find anywhere to go that didn't completely break the bank ;) At any rate, the prices were great for what they provide and we had a lovely time, as I'm sure you will. The only drawback I can think of was that they don't take reservations, so you have to go on the early side if you don't want to wait.

utTgWMi1tKFW3eFfX7kSXg.text: Oh no! One of the worst moments of my life occurred here two weeks ago....One of the waitresses accidentally tripped over my clumsily positioned coat. Hot Thai curry EVERYWHERE. One woman actually had to have her hands dressed in bandages. Oh the guilt! Did I confess? No. Instead I've saved it for Yelp. I'm sure God will see consider it almost as good as a confession box. Seriously though, those low benches might look cool but please take my advice, tuck in your stuff! P.S. The woman looked ok and I'm pretty sure she'll be getting free Thai for life...

jH3-fzFXms45aD9q6jEoQg.text: I first went to this place when I'd only been in London a couple of months. I met with an old friend and, decided where to eat, he said, 'There's this place I know that is really tasty and not too expensive, especially given its location. Oh, and if the line is big, don't worry - it moves really quickly.'I'd say that was about spot on. The line can be off-putting, but don't worry. I don't think I've ever been (I've now been five or six times) and ever walked straight in. That tells me its popular, and the longest I've ever had to wait is half an hour, and that was queuing round the corner!You can browse the simple but varied menu while you wait, and it is definitely worth the wait. The spring rolls are great to start, and both the Thai green curry and Phad Thai are too good for me to have tried anything else.... yet!Great service, great prices, great atmosphere, great food. Get it? Good.

pm2YzKhnzhkfS-VMMCvphw.text: I literally just walked in the door from this place and felt the urge to Yelp about it. I was introduced to Busaba right when I first moved to London and quickly made it one of my go-to spots in Soho. It's one of the few places I've found in London where I don't feel screwed when I get the bill. For instance, tonight I had a starter (Thai calamari), main (Pad Thai) and tea which set me back £17 when it was all said and done. Super convenient for a late dinner after happy hour or just before going out. I recommend hitting it up either before 7pm or after 9:30pm as it gets real busy real quick. The whole no reservations thing means that people queue outside down Wardour. I think I waited about an hour once one long Saturday evening when I was absolutely determined to eat there. Service is good...nothing to write home about....but friendly and quick...and the atmosphere is quite nice once you're settled down at a table surrounded by strangers.Now to the food. I've ordered the Thai calamari just about every time I come to Busaba. It can be quite filling though so I'd recommend sharing. Then I generally go for one of the one of the Pad Thai-esque dishes which are always very good. I tried some of a mate's duck/broccoli tonight and that was good as well...and if you order something which requires rice, get the coconut rice or else you'll be hating yourself (along with me) for not doing so later.

j_2A2ZAVdheWwrtzSzsPxQ.text: Busaba Eathai is one of the best Thai restaurants I've been to. I've had good Thai food from takeaways before, but usually the places are so dingy that you wouldn't want to actually eat there anyway. This place has food that's a lot better than that and it's got a nice interior as well.I wouldn't recommend it for dates or intimate conversations with the gals, though, the communal tables can be a little awkward. Most people studiously pretend to not be able to hear everything being said by the strangers sitting next to them, but it still can be a little weird when you're talking about last night's conquest or that creeping rash.

ZrygyUgK7DLVtk99By5nSg.text: This place is sooooooo good. The best Thai food I have ever had. My boy friend does not normally like Thai food but he loves this place. We went here the first time last week and since then we have gone 3 times. I also told 2 of friends about this place and they tried it last night and they both said it was the best Thai food they have ever had. There is alot of the time a line up so be prepared

4bPGddxfvNR4QFbM2_LEfw.text: This is another OK Asian food place in Soho. The food is generally good, but won't blow your mind. The prices are reasonable, and the service ok. All in all, quite average.

-p6NV3yMHuVufPNkNUsF9A.text: This restaurant was just a short walk from school, and my mates and I stopped by infrequently to get our dose of fusion, super swank Thai food.Expensive, but decent grub and the interiors are incredibly warm. The curries are good if not a little mild, most likely adapted to suit the local palate. The sticky rice is awesome, though.

pZxgi12SOcNLKbMad2E2CQ.text: I had the Green Chicken Curry.  It was a really good choice.  I also tried everything my friends ordered and I came to the conclusion that you can't go wrong here.  The Ginger Ostrich was great.  The prices are really reasonable and the atmosphere is good.  I see why people line up outside in December to have dinner here!

H2xVt3aiEkS4BnekkPdqSw.text: In short, this place is YUUUUMMMMMMMYYYYY !!!!!!I love the layout. The square tables are fun and are great for peole watching. I love this place and I have to go back for more. In short, be adventures and try out things here, you have never tried any where before. You will be pleasantly suprised.This place has a very sheek look to it. Yet, dates in here can be tricky. It gets really loud inside and conversations can be difficult. So keep that in mind.

rP57LaW_eJYvYzQnjxJD6g.text: I have a confession to make to all you Yelpers.  I actually stole a big bottle of the sriracha hot sauce from a Busaba Eathai.  And for that alone, I guess I have to give the place props.Busaba is a decent quick service thai eatery.  Prices are average and the food is consistently good.  Good, not wonderfully great, but decent enough to stomach for lunch and be happy.Busaba doesn't take reservations and be forewarned that you eat group style next to a bunch of strangers, so not particularly good for a date (unless you don't like them much).  The service is quite frequently crappy, but the calamari make up for it.The Soho chapter of this restaurant always seems to have a big queue outside in the evenings so be prepared to wait anytime after 6pm.

1n5cepLzot--uwhcEBVBNQ.text: On our first night in London, I wanted something fun and flavorful in the SoHo area, or somewhere nearby, and we landed on Basuba Eathai.The food was excellent, and the servers were very helpful and friendly. The way the restaurant is laid out, it is possible you may have to share a larger table (8 top) with another party. We shared with a nice group from Norway and had a nice chat with them.Very cool vibe and decor. Be sure to look out for the Golden Buddhas around the restaurant!

efeNtQ4b5QP5hL4uCtVXSQ.text: It's a chain restaurant, but chain restaurants in London apparently don't have the same reputation as in the US, so I decided to still give it a try based on my friend's recommendation. We came here as a group of 6 and there was already a line out of the door which we decided to wait in, but honestly we were seated down within 15 mins. This isn't really a place where diners sit for hours after their meal so just be aware of that. Food was delicious although the noodle dish I got claimed it would be REALLLY spicy and I didn't feel any spicy-ness whatsover. Oh well.

mWDEElmgpwfY0zFqtO1pcg.text: We are here visiting from Canada and stumbled on this restaurant... Mediocre Thai food. Don't bother with the ginger beef. Unless you are a vegetarian.

K_cPw-rft75lF8HHWyJ8NQ.text: Great food and service. We were the oldest patrons there. It obviously is a young people's hangout. We were looking for good Thai food after two weeks in Sicily. This was it.

XRfBshV-VILEPvJuzLnBgw.text: Great Thai food in the heart of Soho, with quite reasonable prices. All day open either for lunch or dinner. Avoid after 19.00 and weekends as it becomes too busy/with long queues. Excellent for a pre-theatre meal. Great variety of Thai meals and nice combos that can save you even more money!

photos.caption: Photo of Busaba Soho - Soho, London, United Kingdom

dbxidn4NJqIg2hTPqcne1Q.text: I came on a Sunday night and the queue was about five parties deep.  It took a while to get seated  even though there were several seats available.  Tables fit 12 - 16 people and we sat next to a random family. One thing to note about this place is that the food comes out as soon as it is ready so do not expect the starters to come out first.  My friend sat there with Pad Thai rapidly cooling on the table while we had our appetizers of vegetable spring rolls, roti, and soft shell crab.  In their defense they do warn you that this would happen when we ordered. I ended up with the chicken butternut squash and it was pretty good with a nice little spice finish to each bite.  This dish along with the roti is what gave the place an additional star.  The most disappointing was the soft shell crab.  Soggy would be too harsh but the batter was soft and bland for lack of a better way to put it.  The sauce that came with it was overpowering with spice and salt.  At that point I could have dipped a napkin in the sauce and it would have been nearly the same.  All said and done it's mediocre Thai food. You won't get sick eating it but it won't be memorable.

photos.caption: Photo of Busaba Soho - Soho, London, United Kingdom. Soft shell crab
Photo of Busaba Soho - Soho, London, United Kingdom

c9sctW7makyOJqPDgkKxhw.text: Having eaten in other locations, I am a Busaba fan, but this is the first Busaba at which I tried the pre-theatre menu (I think only this and the Covent Garden location do it) which is an appetiser and main course for £9.90, which is a freaking amazing deal. You do have to ask for this menu though, it isn't given it to you otherwise, and it is limited. I have to say, I was not into any of the stuff we tried. I didn't like the pad thai that much as it was too sweet for me and I really missed my regular order of pad kwetio. I also could not deal with the calamari texture, but my friend was quite happy to eat it. We had the chicken satay sticks with peanut sauce which was a bit bland unless you really cover it with sauce. I had the ginger beef which came with rice and was decent, but nothing really felt above average to me. Usually, when I order pad kwetio, I am super happy and obsessing over Busaba for a few days. I would come back and try something else I think, perhaps you just have to find the dish that works for you. The restaurant itself is nice. There is shared seating and much needed place to hang your coats on the side. Going to the bathroom, I am always surprised by how heavy the doors are. The lighting is nice, not too dark, not too bright and I enjoy being here.

photos.caption: Photo of Busaba Soho - Soho, London, United Kingdom. Yummy Thai Roti
Photo of Busaba Soho - Soho, London, United Kingdom. Breaded king prawns
Photo of Busaba Soho - Soho, London, United Kingdom. Beef red curry

DatMhlqE-OlETAQ8prEKdA.text: I'm so surprised by the line to get in & the high ranking on yelp. I was underwhelmed by the food and the service. Not sure if I ordered wrong or what but the food was just average (not bad but not great).

DH30RFwmr1RpRNCv8zYypA.text: The food came out cold as did the diners' next to us. We waited 35 minutes for our food the first time and it was cold. The second time it came out was within minutes and it was hot. The food itself was meh. Wouldn't come back. Also there was no toilet paper in the washroom.

GBNRvZlQXWU0GOEeO-6ouw.text: Food just so-so and communal seating = not our favorite dining spot in London.

VfzkA3bTXmgZB8vQ_wbFkg.text: Busaba Eathai Soho is situated right in the centre of Covent Garden and naturally had a long queue outside so it was helpful that we had a reservation. All of the tables were square and could fit 12 diners but they insisted on a strange seating plan because of another reservation which meant that I was on a limb and separate from the rest of my group. It also meant that I was ignored by the waiting staff who weren't interested in my request for a beer. The food was ok but nothing special compared with other venues in London. For the main I had ginger beef which although good, was not much food at all. On the whole, the experience annoyed me so I won't be back.

7OQMxqhl5N0HbsgWj44RKA.text: I had a dream that I was in a hot room, sitting on a bench and being served by a Eastern European waitress and my drink order taken from a Thai gentleman... If only there was someone else fanning me with leaves, I would have thought that I was royalty. Oh Wait, it wasn't a dream. I was actually in a hot building sweating through the pores of my face and back due to lack of ventilation. I was at Busaba Eathai. Despite the restaurant having no cooling system except for a couple of fans in the ceiling which rotate ever so slowly, I enjoyed my time here. I ordered their homemade lemonade which was good and not too sugary but part of me feels like a few drops of bottled lemon was poured in there due to the slightly acidic and unnatural taste. Or maybe that's just the way they make it. After that, during meals, I quite enjoyed their Guava Bellini (Prosecco, guava, strawberry) and ended my night with a glass their 2014 Sauvignon Blanc Villa Montes which I quite liked taking into consideration my picky-ness with wine.For main, which I dived right into, I had their Duck Breast in Chinese Broccoli and Taramind Sauce which was like ... WOAH! Hold on, is this taste real?! I loved it! The tenderness of the duck breast accompanied by well cooked broccoli and a Taramind sauce I want to go hunting for. As sides, I opted for their Phad Phak which, with the crunchiness of the cashews and pine nuts, complimented the Duck dish very well. Low carb meal, you say?! YEAH! If you have been to Wagamama before, you will see some similarities but I prefer Busaba. I would go again and hope that their air cooling system works, if they have one in this location!

photos.caption: Photo of Busaba Soho - Soho, London, United Kingdom. Phad Phak: French bean, broccoli, courgette, baby corn, cashew and pine nut (V) Price: 6:50
Photo of Busaba Soho - Soho, London, United Kingdom. Duck Breast with Chinese Broccoli and Tamarind Sauce . Price : 12:90

Qva1rlLRadwJr05snOp30g.text: Had a REALLY BAD case of food poisoning once which lasted 24 hours. Have never returned since....

j2Vl4nEq6zGNCXNx97KlhA.text: I only had soup, so didn't feel I could honestly give a 5 star rating for the restaurant, I'd give the soup 5 stars though - the spicy chicken lahksa or something to that effect (laksa?). Was afraid I'd just eat the solids and leave the broth, as it was coconut based and usually too rich for my taste, but I was wrong. Once I had a spoonful of the broth I knew it would be gone.Delicious meal, I will be back.

photos.caption: Photo of Busaba Soho - Soho, London, United Kingdom. Spicy chicken soup (laksa?) - delicious

uDeOEWRbXNcKiBV9g-LDOw.text: This place gets pretty packed, and you have to queue in order to get a seat. Large, square tables are shared and communal, which I actually really liked. We ordered:- Mussaman duck curry - what they're known for. Skip it - the duck is just ok and you get very few pieces, and the curry itself is not that good.- Green chicken curry - Amazing. Get it for sure - the smoked chicken is phenomenal and green curry flavors on point.- Thai roti - fun to eat with your hands!- Sen chan pad thai - Really tasty, but not really sure how different it is from their regular pad thai I really enjoyed our meal here, and would recommend any of their locations to anyone who is willing to queue for it.

9D540kCz8MW-TnKSMtAuZA.text: Lovely fast and attentive service, interesting group seating. I ordered the sen chan pad thai which came super fast - love the prawns but wish there was more crab meat. I needed to add some sriracha hot sauce as it wasn't spicy enough for me. But YUM - very delicious and very fresh ingredients. I also ordered a nice refreshing iced ginger tea - was a little pricey (2.70) for the little cup but it is nice for someone who doesn't drink alcoholic cocktails. I'll definitely come back for more!

photos.caption: Photo of Busaba Soho - Soho, London, United Kingdom

Qs2ydOEl4-1bSA-QU7zW6g.text: One of the worst meals I've had in London. The duck massaman was tiny, mediocre, pricy and I had to pay extra for white rice as if it's some posh place and not a chain with communal tables.Will neither return nor recommend.

7pIfpcZci6lJniHfc9O1Dw.text: Friend and I were in the area craving for Thai food and came in for an early dinner and really just beat the dinner rush at around 5pm. By the time we were seated there was a bit of a queue outside. Loved the interior of the restaurant; really pretty, modern, and sleek compared to any other Thai hole in the wall joint I've ever visited. The communal tables made me kinda go 'eeeek' inside. But after being seated, the concept really works. The tables are huge enough that rubbing elbows and overhearing conversations isn't even an issue. Like the piggies we are, my friend and I ordered four plates to share between the two of us.-Som Tam: Our server wasn't kidding when he mentioned that this papaya salad is HOT. The little dish of grated green papaya, dried shrimp and cherry tomatoes looks unassuming enough, but the sauce they use packs a huge punch. As much as I enjoy spicy food, I was in pain eating this. In the best possible way.-Mussaman Duck Curry: Very different, but very delicious! I've never had a duck curry before this, but now I've gotta say I'm a fan. The duck was super tender and the flavor of the curry was unique to other Thai curries I've tried. A little more gritty in texture and much more earthy in flavor. Don't forget the sticky rice with this! -Sen Chan Pad Thai: Reallyyyy good pad thai. Worth splurging on the extra £1 or so for the crabmeat, they're pretty generous about it! The flavors were nice and the noodles were perfect. Definitely one of the better pad thai I've had. -Spicy, Sweet & Sour Fish: The skin was crispy while the inside meat was still moist, and it came served in a sweet and sour sauce topped with chiles. As hot as this dish appeared, the chilies didn't pack a punch like the papaya salad did and my tastebuds said thanks! Definitely worth ordering if you're a fish fan like me. While the food is excellent, service on the other hand is kind of lacking. While they are extremely efficient at getting you into the restaurant, seated, and ordered, it seems that once the food arrives to the table that we become forgotten about. It took us a long time to flag someone down to get our check, and don't even think about trying to get a refill on your water. A few bites into that inferno of a papaya salad, and my water was already gone with no refill in sight. Should have ordered a beer instead!

photos.caption: Photo of Busaba Soho - Soho, London, United Kingdom. pad Thai
Photo of Busaba Soho - Soho, London, United Kingdom. extremely spicy papaya salad
Photo of Busaba Soho - Soho, London, United Kingdom. spicy fish

uN5ABj1KXP-l784uwnL36g.text: Just flew into London and this is the first place we've popped into. We saw a bunch of people waiting outside and naturally thought it was good. Which it was! We aren't Thai fanatics but this was pretty darn tasty. Would come back.

tcZjWWSyX5DXODo9AaqRKA.text: The food was average with prices to be expected for the area. If you want authentic Thai food look elsewhere and boy are there plenty of other/better Thai options in London! Service was a little slow but the food came out really fast.

photos.caption: Photo of Busaba Soho - Soho, London, United Kingdom. Loatian beer. Light and sweet.

qFevYkKTCDInlAE0Z8uu1g.text: Perfect Thai, perfect match of taste right in the city center. It's a must if you want to travel towards the city of Bangkok .

EQQduo4W3n8X_4TsR3V9uA.text: This place was delicious. There was a long line because it was busy (understandably so) but they got us in (a party of 4) quickly and all the food was great and very flavorful. I don't even remember exactly what I ordered but everything we got was delicious.The waitstaff was pleasant and engaging. I'd definitely come back.

S658nGOvdD_FbDQHLMXErA.text: This was recommended my my coworker while I stay in London.  Great place for medium spicy pad tai, shrimp, ginger beef, etc.  I went here twice and the service is good, food is fresh, and seating was open (shared tables with other attendees)Price is reasonable. 4 dishes and 2 beers, it was about 35 pounds.A place i would like to visit again when craving asian food.

gZ2vdVbdU4bM0YwacmX23Q.text: Great place for a quick Thai meal in the centre of London.OK, it doesn't have the pungent aroma of a Bangkok Soi, and the food is most definitely westerised, but it is consistently great.Communal tables mean make for a nice buzzy atmosphere, and it means it's actually one of those few places where it feels OK to eat alone - in London on business means a lot of solo meals and this certaionly beats a big mac and fries or sittting alone at a restaurant trying to look as though your waiting on friends!Everyone loves the thai calamari. It's crack cephalopod, and one order is never enough. If you don't like the squid then you are destined to live a souless unhappy life!All the Thai staples are there, servings are just beyond tapas size, and in general I reckon one dish, the calamari (obviously) and a bowl of rice will see you through. Oh, and the duck is also sublime! No desserts, have never seen anyone have a coffee, and they do usher you out kind of quick. But if you want to have a quick, tasty meal in the centre of London, then this is a great choice, just make sure you have two portions of calamari!!.

z3bb_RPq2Icbr__UIxBeDQ.text: This review is in comparison to other eclectic, fusion, chef-centric Thai places...This definitely was the best meal I had in London.I knew I was coming to this place before I bought my tickets to london. The location is in one of my favorite parts of London. The décor is beautiful and the food...oh man, the food.  A very talented chef put an awesome spin on classics. High quality and superb taste and ingredients a full spectrum menu that provides options for everyone.  The energy in this place is a lot of fun as well. We went in a large group but I had the homemade lemonade, chicken wings (sooo unique and amazing), and the Red Lamb Curry...this was the Star of the meal...really unique and rich. There were other dishes that my family tried like the Chiang Mai Noodles which was also great... but I can't remember everything. FOOD: 5 STARSDÉCOR: 5 STARSSERVICE: 3.5 STARS...BUT WHO CARES WHEN THE FOOD IS SO GOOD. LONDON ISN'T EXACTLY KNOWN FOR GREAT SERVICE.

JMGZbN1f87HIMD67mYSSTQ.text: Not a massive fan of chains but they got this one right. A regular because the food is terribly tasty! I'm not a fan of spicy yet I can't help but ordering the green curry! And don't forget to try the calamari. A decent meal for 12£.

UMPrV1TT3_OLVZa1HVC8kA.text: Great Thai food in Soho in London. Cool tables (most of them are group style seating). This is my 3rd time going back and the food is allways great.

rj1fd0u4KpiWgwY6NAki5Q.text: This is one of the best Thai restaurants in London. They have a really good mix of stir fry dishes, soups and curries. I never know what to have when I go there as it all looks so good. My only complaints are that you never know the size of the portions you're going to get, the main dishes are not all the same and being the greedy man I am I like a decent sized meal. Also the table seating is a bit weird if you're in a semi large group as you end up sitting at different corners of a large square table wiht lots of other people.

cJYgHD8L8dr38NTn4Vt69w.text: Stopped in on the fly, jet-lagged and hungry. The restaurant was packed, cozy and cute. Everything we had was fantastic. The portions were a little on the small side but we ate well and left happy. I think dinner for two with a few glasses of wine was around 40 pounds. A reliable place for a meal, nothing ground breaking but solid. The papaya salad was spicy and crisp. The tofu and spinach was actually quite amazing.

3VIMcHSZkoOGMOeiWD4uHQ.text: I used to love this outlet, communal tables were rad and the decibel level loud.

y32ledESizawBJjeW9aWtg.text: Not too shabby for Thai food!  The taste of each dish is fairly consistent, but it's not always piping hot when it comes out unfortunately.  It's fairly true to form, however the names are ridiculously confusing.  For example, the Prawn Pomelo has neither proper prawn nor pomelo.  It's supposed to be a modernised Western form of "mieng kum" which is a favourite of mine, and it's still pretty tasty :)  It's one of my top 3 Thai restaurants in London, only because they have crab fried rice, one of my favourite dishes.  Some might find it bland, but the way they make it is exactly how it should be.  Also I enjoy the fried shrimp, and their version of pad thai that has crab meat and is supposed to be "spicy."

AOGim0vyx2sjcGlmFWgp4w.text: Came here for dinner Friday night after a couple drinks at Marketplace.  I enjoyed the meal here.  You have to ready for a loud, rowdy dining experience but the food was good.The chili prawns and the Thai calamari were the winners for me.  Both unique dishes I haven't really had a Thai restaurants before (I usually stick to the usual green curry, pad thais, etc).  The only dish I was disappointed with was the jungle curry - it was watery and the curry tasted like grilled chicken.Four dishes and two rice were more than enough for two people.  It's not exactly cheap, but I'd say it was reasonably priced.

rE56AGDb9w9-bcz9pdE3Lg.text: Wow. This place has heaps of reviews already so i will keep this short and sweet.It's dead good here! You should go. If you want.Yes to Thai calamari.Yes to Mussaman duck curry.Yes to Jasmine rice.

_HxhzoN1DuR5gerTj76lww.text: This is my oriental/fusion lunch spot of choice in Soho. The Thai green curry is to die for (though it has a real kick, so don't be expecting a milky concoction designed for Western tastes). I just discovered how much I love coconut rice, and their version is nice and fluffy. Tastes great as well.I've been here several times, and really enjoyed it. Shared tables a la Wagamama, but spacious with room to breathe. I'd go here with friends, or a very good work contact, but not for a business meeting as it's a little too busy for that.The Wardour Street outlet has an unmanned coat rack and very nice bathrooms. There's dark wood everywhere, which keeps it warm in the Winter - but cool in Summer (they also open up the front windows so try and get a space by the front of the restaurant if it's hot). It does get crazy busy in the evening and weekends, you'll regularly£30 for two for a main, side to share and soft drinks. Well worth it as I'd treat that as my main meal of the day, then have something small at home. It's one of those places you can have something hot but not walk away feeling stuffed.

V6lZR12rpk-nRio4oj9nEQ.text: When they open was in my opinion one of the best fusion restaurants in London, but the last two times i was there, my opinion change a little bit, the porcions are smallers and the quality is not like the beginning, I think they lost a regular client, but i hope they recover, is a beautifull place to be with friends, a little bit too much noisebut i recomend to try.FV

admkL_OqLkvtKtIrtFl3FQ.text: Super Thai food, sometimes with a few other Asian dishes thrown in. It's got some long tables and some large square ones, so you'll probably share space unless you've got a big group. There's almost always a huge queue out the door - what does that tell you? The menu's large, the food is quality, and you can get well-fed for not too much money. It's a good place to take a large group, or meet friends. Furthers my theory that everything you need is on Wardour Street.

photos.caption: Photo of Busaba Soho - Soho, London, United Kingdom

_kyYDfPFAQoZMa-mTJth9g.text: Went on a Friday night and the place was very busy with a line out front, but we were still seated shortly after our entire party had arrived.  We were seated at a communal table seating about 12 people total, so our group of 8 shared with another group on the other end of the table.  The food is ... thai inspired more than authentic thai (the chopsticks at the table, rather than the fork and spoon are somewhat of a giveaway), but we all found it very tasty.  We ordered lots of different dishes so that we could try different things.  The ginger beef was very tasty and my wife loved the asparagus fried rice and wild mushroom stir-fry combination.  My personal favorite was the thai calimari which was amazing.  I would probably go back just for that.It was a fun evening, and we would definately go back.

gsRV6S1Bwfm9-wT9YyKa1g.text: Tip: sometimes waiting in line is worth it.  This is one of those times.And it moves pretty fast given the Benihana style communal seating.  They turn tables quickly, so the wait wasn't more than 15 minutes or so.  While I normally don't go for the classic pad thai (it reminds me too much of pub food, which I know is a weird statement) we ordered the version with all sorts of vegetables, along with a spicy chili prawn dish.  Both were delicious.  And while the food came quickly, we didn't feel rushed out the door, either.

LX8f30duHcttegCoNplRMg.text: There is almost always a queue outside, but it moves quite quickly. Not a place to linger that's for sure. It is decide outside, be seated, eat, leave. It is loud/ noisy and you share the table with everyone who can fit there as well. Having said that, it is consistently good food and for London really affordable. I especially enjoy the Mango Lassi with a drop of rose water in it. Everything else is good Thai food (at least from what I know). If you like the rush and bustle, go there, but take friends with you (don't be a threesome they have to wait the longest).

yE4furkacKzbp9TIx0hMnQ.text: Very good for a pile'em in canteen style restaurant. You can tell that from the queue you frequently see outside the restaurant - no reservations at this restaurant. If the windows are open on a nice sunny day, you can even catch a smell of those delicious Thai flavours and spices wafting out of the restaurant.I like their spicy squid and then a plate or bowl of noodles depending on whether I fancy something fried or some warm soup to warm me up on a cold day. Also a decent choice of drinks for non alcoholics.The prices are reasonable for Central London and the food does generally come out fast. And the bonus? It's just across the road from Princi bakery where you can get desserts to die for.

5rMg7KtzvrRc1JMvJP60NA.text: Overall great experience at Busaba Soho. They have amazing and accommodating servers which definitely upped our experience (10/10 service). We initially ordered the 'soyari' (the vegan version of their calamari), the drunken seafood noodles and soft shell crab fried rice - all of which we were very excited for. However, when we received the pad Thai, we found it bland and a bit lacking in depth. As we informed our server and requested a different dish, she was very accommodating and helpful. We ended up getting the seafood curry instead which was very flavourful and rich. (The server did mention after that the Pad Thai is more 'neutral' and light, so perhaps that explains our experience. )Other than the pad Thai, the soymari was pretty good (which the portion was slightly larger for ~£7), the rice was very flavourful and curry was delicious. All in all, we spent around £41, for the appetizer, fried rice, seafood curry (new dish) and coconut rice. I would definitely return just for the service, but also because I would love to try out the rest of the menu. Would definitely recommend!

photos.caption: Photo of Busaba Soho - Soho, London, United Kingdom. Seafood drunken noodles (close), soft shell crab pad Thai (dish), soyari (bowl)

CZN_creTangUpPukJexvAA.text: Nice modern Thai restaurant and we had a very nice waitress.  I ordered the orange chicken which wasn't the most "Thai" thing I could have ordered, but it was good and had good flavor and was a good portion.  My boyfriend had a more traditional dish and he enjoyed it very much, (I apologize for not remembering what he ordered).  We really like the location, it didn't appear to have any outdoor seating, but if you sit by the window they open the front windows on nice days allowing for a nice breeze.  Very pleasant and relaxing eating experience.  It wasn't the best food I've ever eaten, but it was good and I'd eat here again for the experience.

CejPWCeIwmzkvADCRxnKsg.text: Wasn't expecting it to be so good. The calamari is a MUST. I've never had it made the way it was. It was so flavorful and tasted great!I had the Sen chan pad Thai which was pretty good. I love wok since it's pretty light. Portions were great. The only thing is I wish it was spicier. It had a double chili pepper sign (supposed to be spicy) and I added on extra chili but it still wasn't spicy... maybe that's just be though. My friend had the classic pad thai which was also good although he said he preferred mine. The classic beer was really good as well. And they DO have a student discount if you use your StudentBeans card which saved us some money as well.My only regret was that we didn't have whatever the table next to us was having because that looked AMAZING as well.... next time for sure!£47: Sen chan pad Thai + Classic pad thai + water + 1 beer + fried calamari appetizer

photos.caption: Photo of Busaba Soho - Soho, London, United Kingdom. Fried calamari. REALLY good.
Photo of Busaba Soho - Soho, London, United Kingdom. Sen chan pad Thai. Would recommend asking for extra spice if you like spicy food.

wno3pkV5EEHnvOpJgqsXjw.text: My girlfriend and I came here to fulfill our Thai food cravings, this place is pretty popular! We ordered the pad Thai, fried rice, and chicken. All were decent but we wish there was an option for it to be spicier OR offer a spice rack. The staff were pretty nice and the service was efficient -- was lacking the authencity of it.

photos.caption: Photo of Busaba Soho - Soho, London, United Kingdom. Red mule - with sliced ginger on top
Photo of Busaba Soho - Soho, London, United Kingdom. Fooood

yWEBpI77jBzC9tkjUuyQjA.text: For our last night in London, we were hanging out in Piccadilly Circus and looking for some good Thai food. The positive reviews ended up leading us to Busaba. While it isn't located directly in Piccadilly Circus, it was a short walk and easy to find. We were there for a later dinner and were sat without having to wait. Unfortunately, the only real negative about our experience is the communal seating. The dining room has many large tables and benches and if you are a small party, you share the tables with other people. I really don't care to eat like that. Luckily, some of the groups were finishing up and we had some breathing room after a few minutes. We tried the Bang-Kick Prawns for an appetizer and they were great. They weren't overly spicy, but did have a good kick of flavor. For my entree, I had the Sweet & Sour Chicken and my wife had the Black Pepper Beef. Our food was served quickly and both entrees were delicious. Pay attention to the spicy ratings on the dishes. My wife's was rated pretty low on the spicy scale and it was definitely more than we expected (still great though). The serving size was about right, but we didn't realize that side items are ala carte. Had I known, I would have ordered some rice or something to go along with it.The food and service were great and the prices were very reasonable. I probably would have rated this place a four, but my wife raved about how much she loved it. She said it was the best Thai she had ever had, so I guess that deserves a 5 star rating.

photos.caption: Photo of Busaba Soho - Soho, London, United Kingdom. Exterior
Photo of Busaba Soho - Soho, London, United Kingdom. Entry
Photo of Busaba Soho - Soho, London, United Kingdom. Interior / Communal Seating

M98WdXQpRQ05r2b1GG65kQ.text: Awful to bad, not one person in the kitchen must be Thai.  Truly the worst thai food I've ever had. I really feel bad giving this review because the staff was so nice and friendly , but I can't recommend it. The place has a great atmosphere. They asked us how our meal was and we were honest, but I feel bad about it, but it really wasn't good.  Hopefully they will understand our review and  improve because it's a great place and location. It's been around a long time, so I'm sure it will last. But I hope they go back to what it must've been before or something.I have to update the review a bit, they listened to us, comped pretty much the  whole meal, but I still feel bad. I hope the food is normally better, it is the first time we  have been here, I will come back to see.

sQvDsKExxIDnx3H_tniMBA.text: I have no idea how this place survives. First while I was waiting to be seated I was asked twice if I was OK. I had to explain that I wanted a table. After this the service was actually good. I had the classic Pad Thai and it was horrible. It showed up and looked a very sad shade of grey. The taste was really off. I was able to make it edible with added hot sauce. The shrimp seemed cheap and low quality. This is anything but authentic Thai food. I recommend skipping this place.

Hy_V7TLNU9Iaj3qfBnmkAA.text: Good appetizer Frawn Crackers, Jasmine Beef I think is what's it's called highlights of our dinner. Ambience is thumbs up and good service.

wBUGlg1B1673ncvjtDM4iQ.text: An all time favourite place of mine. Love the ambience, the food and service is great. I've been coming here for years and I'm never disappointed. I bring all my friends from out of town and they love it to. Thai calamari is just the best!

O1tf5Yrx8WUvjCtAkXCfYg.text: The atmosphere was pretty cool and the staff were very friendly and accommodating. However the food (chicken pad thai and classic pad thai) was pretty tasteless, and the "sriracha" sauce they had on the table also had little to no flavour. It would be better if we could customize spice levels as well to add some flavour and appeal to a larger demographic. The communal seating may be a bit awkward when crowded, and the restaurant layout was not the best as people will be constantly be walking behind you and hitting you in the back with their bags/elbows. I would not recommend Busaba as your first choice if you're looking for legitimate Thai food in London.

photos.caption: Photo of Busaba Soho - Soho, London, United Kingdom. Chicken pad thai

jcaSPOUsGAhxoKbcDq25YQ.text: Being a Thai food aficionado, the Busaba Thai in Soho did not disappoint. As a matter of fact, we dined here two times during our stay in London. One has to queue in order to dine in this restaurant, but it was well worth the wait.The restaurant is relatively spacious with rows of communal tables and Buddha images everywhere as the main motif, we opted for the set dinner menu that comes with appetizer and main entrée. I started with a small plate of fish cakes with cucumber and peanut sauce relish while I selected Ginger beef stir fry with Thai pepper, chili, onion served over Jasmine rice for my main. it was delicious, well portioned and good paired with a cold bottle of Thai beer. the customer service is awesome they do their best to accommodate the clients as soon as possible. For under £20, this place is a must whenever you are in London

photos.caption: Photo of Busaba Soho - Soho, London, United Kingdom
Photo of Busaba Soho - Soho, London, United Kingdom. Beef with basil leaves
Photo of Busaba Soho - Soho, London, United Kingdom. Chicken and pumpkin stir fry

wur8Hl2wyzCEKe-S28TMoQ.text: The slowest service in all of London.  Just know that if you're going to come here. It's expensive. It's loud. And the service is ludicrously slow. And when the food finally arrives it's so underwhelming. It's like "huh, I waited all this time for this??" And then it's rather bland too. Do not order the Classic Pad  Thai. It's easily, hands down the worst I've ever eaten. I actually had to return it. The waitress was lovely and seemed to totally understand. And because she was so nice I bravely ordered something new in its place. And now I'm nervously waiting and waiting for the new order. But all in all this experience has been kinda frustrating and bizarre. I'd give this place a miss if I were you.

-fR0t13ZXgSe_QnNjhXkew.text: Was recommended by another flight attendant so we decided to check it out. I loved the atmosphere. The colours, furniture, accents, really a lot of fun. Started with the calamari and it was ok...well prepared but missing something so I added Sriracha and it boosted the flavour ten fold. I then asked for Asian greens and the chicken satay....whoops. The satay was missing a peanut taste to it and the greens were so wet and soggy. My friend ordered dry sweet potato fries...dry as the Sahara dry. Also the Pad Thai and she hated it. The jumbo shrimp were cocktail shrimp and it tasted like no care was put into it. I will give it a second go ONLY because of the staff. They were quite attentive and all smiled save for our first one who was grumpy...the rest made up for it. A special thank you to the serving staff and especially the young lad from Colombia (we had an opportunity to chat) he was tops and so kind. They did well in choosing the service staff...if only their kitchen staff cared just as much. Give it a try...it could of been an off night when I went.

photos.caption: Photo of Busaba Soho - Soho, London, United Kingdom

uoQZOKy15QF4673dQJbgFQ.text: DRINKS:Ordered Tempranillo Rose. It wasn't chilled well. SERVICE:The wait staff were all friendly but thought they were not attentive. My wine, appetizer and main dish arrived all at the same time, with the wrong drink. I ordered 2nd serving of rice and it took a while to come. I asked for a check twice and had to wait for a while alsoDECOR/ATMOSPHERE:NiceFOOD/PRICE:I thought the food was priced reasonably, although was a bit surprised to be charged for rice at 2.50 (GBP).I ordered Chicken Liver cooked in dark soy for appetizer. It was just so so. I usually like liver when it uses the low temperature to cook so it doesn't smell and also it is tender and melt on your tongue. But this was one hard and smelled a bit too liver-ish. I ordered curry flavored prawns and eggs for the main dish. It was good. no complaints.

o37UiKyLRizPo0B5ujhzUg.text: Another visit at Busaba Soho . Chicken livers and Som tam salad are amazing . Staff professional , not disturbing you where you are on your own .

photos.caption: Photo of Busaba Soho - Soho, London, United Kingdom

qQDFc-KnHkgJ0-AAXv4-cw.text: If you want some really delish Thai food, you found it here.  Wide range of options. The fried calamari appetizer is amazing! I ordered a chicken dish from the grilled menu and it was pretty good.I live in the US but if I'm back in town I'll definitely stop by here. Nice atmosphere too. Pretty chill.

U7bEX41pXyeZ8uLnJt1kRA.text: Tasty food.  Great crowd.  Community tables.   Not the best Thai food I've had, but pretty good.  The pandan wrapped chicken was delicious.

ejFwmq92eZaeAyuYxz6g6A.text: I've had GREAT Thai food in LA, NYC and SF so I kinda think I know what I'm talking about...maybe out of my a$$ at time?It was odd to me that their Curry doesn't come with rice and I had to pay extra for it, but then again I'm a fat American used to ridiculous portions.The green curry had awesome flavor, but the chicken in it was flavorless. I assume the curry base was made ahead of time and the meat was cooked separately and added in when ordered (understandable, but they need to curry up that chicken)The crab fried rice had no "wok air". If you don't know what that is, it's the flavor you get in most Asian food cooked in a wok. Food that is cooked with extreme heat and fast speed has "wok air" Their fried rice is something you can cook on your weak stove at home.Chicken Satay was odd, once again, chicken was flavorless, so the initial bite give you a great smoky flavor, but once that was gone it was like chewing on an eraser, the peanut sauce lacked peanuts which is a crime.

6HE1z67m8mc2jY2vcqwXPQ.text: Great food! Loved the ambiance. Must try the green curry and pad Thai noodles. The edamame and spring rolls were delicious as well. Damn good guava Bellini.

photos.caption: Photo of Busaba Soho - Soho, London, United Kingdom. Green pumpkin curry and guava Bellini

359QlaU5tE68pnEqyJtiow.text: Over priced. Ordered red mullet curry. The soup was tasty but the fish didn't have have flavor.

eDqpL9eVAYIqkrBG2LOBVg.text: Tried this place on my visit to London a few weeks ago.  The atmosphere is really dark and trendy with multiple parties sitting at 1 table.  There was a line of 20 people outside but it moved in about 15 minutes.  Food was moderately priced and the service was very good when we got inside.  Get the calamari! Very different but a delicious take.  Also try their cool juice/muddled drinks.  Will definitely return next time I am in London.

1AjGTOFmlU2hwybShRh4hQ.text: Superb thai food, excellent service and a lovely shared-table atmosphere.  Only downside is the obligatory 10-15 minute queue to get seated.Make sure you order a 'Guava Collins' smoothie, really good as a accompaniment to the spicy dishes.

sZm8ML_75X7a7hquPhj69A.text: This is a Thai restaurant, and every time I have gone there has been a queue outside, and there is a good reason for this, the food!!! Don't be put off by the queues, it goes quickly, but if you hate queues, try going at lunch.Busaba Eethai have taken Thai food and added a modern taste, but it is still delicious. All in all, it is reasonably priced.
